''[[Final Score]]''
''[[Match of the Day]]''
''[[BBC Breakfast]]'' | residence = [[Sheffield|Sheffield, South Yorkshire]], England | occupation = Journalist, television presenter | known_for = | height = {{height|ft=6|in=6}}{{cite web |last=Walker |first=Dan |date=21 October 2009 |title=Dressed for success?|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/danwalker/2009/10/dressed_for_success.html |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |accessdate=29 January 2014}} }} '''Daniel Meirion Walker''' (born 19 March 1977){{Cite web |url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=VsF68UD%2BmQQlZCtLFSgUOg&scan=1 |title=Index entry |accessdate=3 October 2016 |work=FreeBMD |publisher=ONS}}{{cite interview|url=http://www.johnsmedley.com/blog/2013/11/13/the-real-dan-walker/ |last=Walker |first=Dan |title=The Real Dan Walker |publisher=[[John Smedley (industrialist)|John Smedley]] |location=[[Matlock, Derbyshire]] |date=13 November 2013 |accessdate=7 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714153559/http://www.johnsmedley.com/blog/2013/11/13/the-real-dan-walker/ |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df=dmy }} is an English journalist and television presenter, best known for presenting [[BBC]] television programmes including ''[[Football Focus]]'' (2009–present) and ''[[BBC Breakfast]]'' (2016–present). He also presents shows on [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] and has presented sport on the [[BBC News (TV Channel)|BBC News Channel]], as well as regularly reporting for ''[[Final Score]]'' and ''[[Match of the Day]]''. ==Early life== Walker was born in [[Crawley]], [[Sussex]], the son of the minister of a local church and a Welsh mother. He lived in Crawley until the age of 18, where he attended Ifield Primary School, Three Bridges Middle School, and [[Hazelwick School|Hazelwick Secondary School]].{{cite web|title = BBC Presenter, Dan Walker, talks about his time in Crawley - Crawley TV|url = http://crawleytv.co/crawleyhistory/dan-walker/|website = Crawley TV|accessdate = 2015-08-06}} He supports [[Crawley Town F.C.]]{{cite news |url=http://www.crawleyobserver.co.uk/sport/crawley-town-fc/walker-calls-for-more-fans-as-crawley-climb-league-ladder-1-3408490 |title=Walker calls for more fans as Crawley climb league ladder |work=Crawley and Horley Observer |date=11 January 2012 |accessdate=29 December 2012}} He earned a BA (Hons) degree in History in 1998 and an MA degree in Journalism Studies in 1999 at the [[University of Sheffield]].{{cite magazine |author= |title=My Sheffield |url=http://youruniversity.group.shef.ac.uk/features/my-sheffield/ |magazine=Your University |publisher=[[The University of Sheffield]] |year=2016 |access-date=3 October 2016}} ==Career== ===Radio=== Walker's professional broadcasting career started with work experience at Sheffield's [[Hallam FM]]. He gained the work experience after winning a competition for young sports commentators. In 1999, Walker moved to a full-time career with a 4-year stint as a sports presenter and commentator for Manchester's [[Key 103]] radio. In his time at the station he presented the regular midweek sports show (often broadcasting from [[UEFA Champions League]] matches at [[Manchester United]]'s [[Old Trafford]] ground) and also appeared as the resident sports correspondent for Mike Toolan's breakfast show.{{Citation needed|date=February 2013}} ===Television=== {{more citations needed|section|date=June 2017}} Walker moved into television with a six-month spell at [[Granada Television]] in Manchester, appearing as a commentator on the ''Football League Review'' show before joining BBC regional news programme [[BBC North West Tonight|North West Tonight]]. During this time, he was nominated for a number of awards and won the [[Royal Television Society]] Sports Award in 2005 for Regional Sports Presenter of the Year. He was unable to attend the ceremony because he was covering the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] final in [[Istanbul]]. In 2006, Walker started working in London and in 2008 started presenting and reporting at [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]], [[The Open Championship|The Open]], [[Aintree]], [[Ascot Racecourse|Ascot]] and [[The Derby]] at [[Epsom Downs Racecourse|Epsom]] as well as the [[Six Nations Championship|6 Nations]]. In August 2009, Walker took over from [[Manish Bhasin]] as the presenter of [[Football Focus]]. Walker also presents the web-based Friday preview ''Friday Focus'' and writes a [[blog]] on the BBC website where he discusses the show and football in general. Walker was part of the BBC Sport team covering the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://wscdn.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2010/04_april/22/worldcup.shtml |title=BBC Press Release April 2010 |publisher=Wscdn.bbc.co.uk |date=22 April 2010 |accessdate=17 November 2011}} He spent the tournament travelling from [[Cape Town]] at the start of the tournament to [[Johannesburg]] for the final in a double-decker bus, filming packages to be shown both as part of the TV coverage and online, and providing commentary and news via the BBC's online channels and Twitter. The bus visited a diverse selection of places along its 6,000 km journey – from townships and social projects to sites of cultural and historic significance, with the intention being to provide UK viewers with a flavour of the host nation both inside and out of the stadia. On 26 November 2011, [[Gary Speed]] appeared as a guest on ''Football Focus'' with Walker. The two men spent a total of about four hours with each other on the day. Walker said of Speed: "I always found him to be kind, funny, intelligent and insightful. I found him to be a top bloke and really enjoyed his company." The following morning on Sunday 27 November 2011, Walker received the news that Speed had died at his house in Cheshire. Walker said that he was "stunned" by Speed's death{{cite web|author=Walker, Dan |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/danwalker/2011/11/gary_speed_leaves_a_huge_whole.html |title=Gary Speed leaves a huge hole in football |publisher=BBC |date=27 November 2011 |accessdate=29 December 2012}} and that he was "incredibly saddened". He had known Speed for quite a long time and had played football with him in a charity match two months earlier.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15910712 |title=Football Focus's Dan Walker saddened |work=BBC Sport|date=27 November 2011 |accessdate=29 December 2012}} In March 2012, Walker said that he was "staggered by the depth of feeling and shock" on the Sunday when Speed's death was announced.{{cite web|author=Walker, Dan |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/danwalker/2012/03/cardiff_in_full_voice_to_comme.html |title=Cardiff in full voice to commemorate Gary Speed |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=29 December 2012}} In addition to Walker's TV work, he presented ''Afternoon Edition'' every Monday-Thursday {{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04kfzpy |title=BBC Radio 5 live - Afternoon Edition |publisher=BBC |date=4 March 2015 |accessdate=4 March 2015}} on [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] until 2016, and has previously hosted shows on the station's evening sports output.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}} In 2015 and 2018, Walker guest presented episodes of ''[[The One Show]]''. In 2016, Walker replaced [[Bill Turnbull]] as presenter of ''[[BBC Breakfast]]''. His first show aired on 29 February and he currently co-presents the programme from Monday to Wednesday with [[Louise Minchin]]. Dan Walker presented the 'Clash of the Titans' segment of the ''[[Sport Relief 2016|Sport Relief]]'' telethon. Along with that, Walker also reported for the [[2016 Olympics]].{{citation needed|date=June 2017}} ==Charity work== Walker is an active patron of several charities including the [[Sheffield Children's Hospital]] charity,{{cite news|title=Jess at City Hall for Children’s Hospital charity |url=http://www.sheffieldnewsandsport.com/2012/11/20/jess/ |work=Sheffield News & Sport |accessdate=1 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203052207/http://www.sheffieldnewsandsport.com/2012/11/20/jess/ |archivedate=3 December 2013 |df=dmy }} alongside [[Jessica Ennis-Hill]], [[Michael Vaughan]] and [[Lee Westwood]]. He holds a golf day for the charity every year, laid the first brick on the new hospital wing in 2015 and, in 2016, officially opened the £2.3 million [[Magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]] scanner.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} ==Personal life== Walker has been married to Sarah Walker since 2001, and they have three children. The family reside in [[Sheffield|Sheffield, South Yorkshire]].{{citation needed|date=June 2017}} Walker became a [[Christianity|Christian]] at the age of 12.{{cite web|url=http://www.gracemagazine.org.uk/articles/historical/walker.htm |title=Dan Walker - an interview |publisher=Gracemagazine.org.uk |date= |accessdate=20 January 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414132418/http://www.gracemagazine.org.uk/articles/historical/walker.htm|archivedate=14 April 2012}} He made a decision not to work on a Sunday once he started employment and has maintained that throughout his career.{{cite web|url=http://www.e-n.org.uk/p-4700-Sport-&-Sundays.htm |title=Sport & Sundays |publisher=E-n.org.uk |date= |accessdate=17 November 2011}} He belongs to the [[Evangelicalism|Evangelical]] branch of Christianity.{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/feb/14/bbc-breakfast-dan-walker-creationist-fact-fiction|title=Dan Walker: it’s tricky to trust a presenter who feels God got him the job - Catherine Bennett|first=Catherine|last=Bennett|date=14 February 2016|website=the Guardian|accessdate=21 October 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=3692874|name=Dan Walker}} *[http://www.lordsday.co.uk/Dan%20Walker.htm Dan Walker profile], ''Day One Magazine'' (2008) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120414132418/http://www.gracemagazine.org.uk/articles/historical/walker.htm Dan Walker profile], ''Grace Magazine'' (2002) *[http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/features/2581009/Christian-footie-host-Dan-Walker-wont-work-Sunday.html Christian BBC footie host who refuses to work on a Sunday], ''The Sun'', 11 August 2009 *[http://tvnewsroom.co.uk/qanda/answers.php?page=danwalker.htm Dan Walker TV Newsroom Questions and Answers 2006] *{{BBC programme | title=Afternoon Edition}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Walker, Dan}} [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Sheffield]] [[Category:BBC newsreaders and journalists]] [[Category:BBC North West newsreaders and journalists]] [[Category:BBC sports presenters and reporters]] [[Category:English sports journalists]] [[Category:Christian Young Earth creationists]] [[Category:English Christians]] [[Category:English television presenters]] [[Category:English people of Welsh descent]] [[Category:People from Crawley]]

The '''Estonian Border Guard''' ({{lang-et|Eesti Piirivalve}}) was the [[national security]] agency responsible for the border security of [[Estonia]]. It was subordinate to the [[Minister of the Interior (Estonia)|Ministry of the Interior]]. The Border Guard also assisted with Search and Rescue missions. In 2010, the organization was superseded by the [[Police and Border Guard Board]].
==History== ===Formation and disbandment (1918-1940)===
On November 14, 1918, [[admiral]] [[Johan Pitka]] organized a meeting to discuss the guarding of borders of the freshly established [[Republic of Estonia]]. On November 18, 1918, the Border Guard government ({{lang-et|Piirivalvevalitsus}}) was established, with [[captain]] Leopold Tõnson leading it. Until 1 January 1919, the agency was subordinate to the [[Estonian Defence League]] Council of Elders ({{lang-et|Kaitseliidu Vanematekogu}}), but was then subordinated to the Ministry of Finance. Since 1 February 1919 until the end of the [[Estonian War of Independence]] the borders were guarded by the military. Since 15 February 1919 until May 1921 the crossing of borders was checked by the Republic's Border Control Government ({{lang-et|Vabariigi Piirikontrolli Valitsus}}). On 30 May 1922, the border guard agency was subordinated to the Ministry of the Interior. Following the recommendation of Minister of the Interior, [[Kaarel Eenpalu]], the Border Guard Government ({{lang-et|Piirivalve Valitsus}}) (not to be confused with the previous Border Guard government) was established on 20 September 1922. [[Lieutenant colonel]] [[Ants Kurvits]] was appointed to lead the organization on 1 November 1922, which is also considered the official formation date of the Estonian Border Guard. [[Lieutenant colonel]] [[Arved Engmaa]] became his deputy.
On 1 December 1922, the Estonian government approved the structure of the agency, consisting of: a headquarters, departments, districts, and cordons. The headquarters started work in January 1923, at the White hall of the [[Toompea Castle]]. Positions were manned with reserve officers from the military and conscripts serving under a one year contract. By May 20, 1923, all control over the border was transferred from the Defence Forces to the border guard. There were eight district stations: Tallinn, Läänemaa, Pärnu, Valga, Petseri, Tartu, Peipsi and Narva. On 1 December 1923, Valga station was joined with Petseri, and on 1 July, Tartu station was joined with Peipsi, and Pärnu was joined with Läänemaa into Lääne station.
On 16 February 1923, a corporation for officers was established. On 16 June 1927, a similar corporation was established for the conscripts. Until the mid 30's, the legal ground for the activities of the border guard was based on an old law, established under the Russian Empire. On 5 June 1936, a new Border Guard Act was entered into force. Despite legal agreements with the [[Soviet Union]], a tragic incident occurred on 8 February 1938, when Soviet border guards entered Estonian territory and killed two Estonian border guards and one civilian. On the 10th anniversary of the Border Guard, the agency received its flag. In 1940, the agency was partially disbanded by the [[Occupation of the Baltic states|occupying Soviet Union forces]]. The eastern border structures were demolished. By then there were roughly 1100 border guards. Large number of Estonian Border Guard officers were repressed and sent to [[Gulag]]s.<ref name=":0"/>
===Restoration and unification (1990-2010)=== [[File:RIAN archive 472705 Estonian customs office in Narva.jpg|thumb| Estonian customs office in Narva during 1991.]][[File:Luhamaa piiripunkt.jpg|thumb|[[Luhamaa]] border crossing in 2005.]] The restoration of Estonian Border Guard began with the formation of the Estonian Home Defence ({{lang-et|Eesti Kodukaitse}}), a volunteer organization, created in response to the attack on [[Toompea]] by the [[Intermovement]] on 15 May 1990. The guarding of borders was organized with volunteers. The situation with borders was dire - the border was unmarked, there was no communication equipment nor transport, not to mention work and living spaces. Furthermore, Soviet troops were still residing in Estonia.
On 20 September 1990, the Minister of State [[Raivo Vare]] formed a commission, which was tasked with establishing control over Estonian borders. On October 1, training of future border guards began. On 15 October, an economic border defence service was established inside the Home Defence organization. An act regarding the economic border of Estonia was passed on 22 October and checkpoints began work three days later.
The restoration date of the Estonian Border Guard is considered to be November 1, 1990, when the government approved 27 permanent checkpoints. On 15 September, Remniku Training Center began operating in Ida-Virumaa, with Johan Saar appointed to head it. The Estonian National Border Guard Board ({{lang-et|Eesti Riiklik Piirikaitseamet}}) was formed on April 8, 1991. During that period, the situation on the southern border was tense because [[Riga]]'s [[OMON]] continuously assaulted Estonian checkpoints. On 15 November, border control was established on highway checkpoints, railway crossings, trains, harbours and airports. On 28 February 1992, the institution was reformed into the Estonian Border Guard ({{lang-et|Eesti Piirivalveamet}}), under the control of the Ministry of the Interior. On March 9, the Border Guard College began work. On 1 July 1992, a [[Travel visa|visa regime]] was established on the border. On November 1, 1992, the organization received its former flag.
On November 16, 1992, the [[Finnish Border Guard]] donated the first three ships (PVL-100, PVL-101, PVL-102) to the naval department. In 1993, the [[Police and Border Guard Aviation Group|National Border Guard Squadron]] was established, which began operating with two [[L-410]] airplanes donated by Germany. These were later supplemented with four [[Mil Mi-8]] helicopters. In June 1993, [[Tarmo Kõuts]] became the head of the organization and the corporation for officers was re-established. In 2000, [[colonel]] [[Harry Hein]] became the next head of the organization. During that time, employment of conscripts for border control duties was seized and the organization transitioned to a fully professional staff.
After Estonia joined the [[EU]] and [[NATO]], the border guard went through a reform, establishing the [[Schengen Area]] in Estonia. In 2005, [[lieutenant colonel]] [[Roland Peets]] became the head of the organization. Estonia officially joined the Schengen Area on 21 December 2007. On January 1, 2010, the Estonian Border Guard was joined with the [[Estonian Police]] to form a new unified organization called the [[Police and Border Guard Board]]. The organizations duties were taken over by the Border Guard Board subdivision.<ref name=":1"/>

The '''Fascist Defence Force (FDF)''' was the [[paramilitary]] section of the [[British Union of Fascists]] (BUF).<ref name="pugh">Martin Pugh, Hurrah For The Blackshirts!: Fascists and Fascism in Britain Between the Wars, pp. 133-135, Random House</ref>
It was established in August 1933 by [[Oswald Mosley]], after the BUF acquired its headquarters, the ''Black House'' (formerly ''The Whitelands Teacher Training College'') in [[King's Road]], [[Chelsea, London|Chelsea]]. The Fascist Defence Force comprised three hundred men; they wore black shirts and black trousers (their shirts, modelled on Mosley's [[fencing]] jacket, were akin to [[polo neck]] sweaters) as well as six badges and stripes to denote rank. They also wore a red armband with the BUF symbol of a flash of lightning in a circle, representing "action within unity".<ref name="pugh">Martin Pugh, Hurrah For The Blackshirts!: Fascists and Fascism in Britain Between the Wars, pp. 133-135, Random House</ref>
An elite unit within the Fascist Defence Force, the '''I Squad''', functioned as Mosley's personal bodyguards; they also wore black fencing jackets, but with black leather breeches and boots.<ref name="pugh">Martin Pugh, Hurrah For The Blackshirts!: Fascists and Fascism in Britain Between the Wars, pp. 133-135, Random House</ref>
The Force maintained thirty motor vehicles, including five rapid transportation vans specially equipped with [[Chain-link fencing|wire mesh]] windows and plating at the sides for protection against missiles, each of which had a seating capacity of 20 persons.<ref name="pugh">Martin Pugh, Hurrah For The Blackshirts!: Fascists and Fascism in Britain Between the Wars, pp. 133-135, Random House</ref>
The FDF was commanded by Eric Piercy, a [[Special Constabulary]] Inspector and ex-[[insurance agent]]; his second-in-command was Ian Dundas, a former [[Royal Navy]] officer.<ref name="pugh">Martin Pugh, Hurrah For The Blackshirts!: Fascists and Fascism in Britain Between the Wars, pp. 133-135, Random House</ref>

'''The Federal Information Security Modernization Act of 2014''' ([https://www.congress.gov/113/plaws/publ283/PLAW-113publ283.pdf Pub.L. 113-283], S. 2521; commonly referred to as FISMA Reform) was signed into federal law by President [[Barack Obama]] on December 18, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=S.2521 - Federal Information Security Modernization Act of 2014|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/senate-bill/2521/text|website=congress.gov|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|accessdate=9 March 2017}}</ref> Passed as a response to the increasing amount of [[Cyberattack|cyber attacks]] on the federal government, it amended existing laws to enable the federal government to better respond to cyber attacks on departments and agencies.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moore|first1=Jack|title=FROM FITARA TO FISMA REFORM: 5 KEY TECH BILLS PASSED BY CONGRESS IN 2014|url=http://www.nextgov.com/cio-briefing/2014/12/fitara-fisma-reform-5-key-tech-bills-passed-congress-2014/101916/|website=NextGov|accessdate=9 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Bennett|first1=Cory|title=Federal data security bill heads to Obama's desk|url=http://thehill.com/policy/cybersecurity/226740-federal-data-security-bill-heads-to-presidents-desk|website=The Hill|accessdate=9 March 2017}}</ref>
An earlier version of the legislation was proposed by [[United States House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform|House Oversight and Government Reform]] Chairman [[Darrell Issa]] and co-sponsored by the Committee's Ranking Member [[Elijah Cummings|Elijah Cummins]] as H.R.1163 Federal Information Security Amendments Act of 2013<ref>{{cite web|title=H.R.1163 - Federal Information Security Amendment Act of 2013|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/1163?|website=congress.gov|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|accessdate=27 November 2018}}</ref>. The bill was passed the U.S. House of Representatives on a vote of 416-0.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://harvardnsj.org/2014/02/the-current-landscape-of-cybersecurity-policy-legislative-issues-in-the-113th-congress/|title=FISMA Legislative Origin|last=Kominsky|first=Mitchell|date=February 6, 2014|website=Harvard Law National Security Journal|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The final version of the legislation was introduced to the [[United States Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs]] by [[Thomas Carper]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]–[[Delaware|DE]]) on June 24, 2014 and passed December 8, 2014 in the Senate and December 10, 2014 in the House.

{{lang|el|Ελευθερία ή θάνατος}}
"Freedom or Death" |capital = [[Nafplio]] |common_languages = [[Greek language|Greek]] |religion = Greek Orthodox | government_type = [[Unitary state|Unitary]] [[presidential system|presidential]] [[republic]] | title_leader = [[President of Greece|President of the Executive]] | leader1 = [[Alexandros Mavrokordatos]] {{small|(first)}} | year_leader1 = 1822–1823 | leader2 = [[Andreas Zaimis]] {{small|(last)}} | year_leader2 = 1826–1827 | title_deputy = [[List of heads of state of Greece|Governor]] | deputy1 = [[Ioannis Kapodistrias]] | year_deputy1 = 1827–1831 | deputy2 = [[Augustinos Kapodistrias]] | year_deputy2 = 1831–1832 |legislature = [[Greek_National_Assemblies|National Assembly]] |currency = [[phoenix (currency)|Phoenix]] |image_map = Greece1830EN.png |image_map_caption = }} The '''First Hellenic Republic''' ({{lang-el|Αʹ Ελληνική Δημοκρατία}}) is a [[historiography|historiographical term]] for the provisional [[Greece|Greek]] state during the [[Greek War of Independence]] against the [[Ottoman Empire]]. It is used to emphasize the constitutional and democratic nature of the revolutionary regime prior to the establishment of the independent [[Kingdom of Greece]], and associate this period of Greek history with the later [[Second Hellenic Republic|Second]] and [[Third Hellenic Republic|Third]] Republics. ==History== In the first stages of the 1821 uprising, various areas elected their own [[Greek local statutes|regional governing councils]]. These were replaced by a central administration at the [[First National Assembly of Epidaurus]] in early 1822, which also adopted the first [[Greek Constitution of 1822|Greek Constitution]], marking the birth of the modern Greek state. The councils continued in existence however, and central authority was not firmly established until 1824/1825. The new state was not recognized by the Great Powers of the day, which, after initial successes, was threatened with collapse both from within due to [[Greek civil wars of 1824–1825|civil war]] and from without through the victories of the Turco-Egyptian army of [[Ibrahim Pasha of Egypt|Ibrahim Pasha]]. By 1827 the Greek revolution had almost been extinguished on the mainland, but by this time the Great Powers had come to agree to the formation of an autonomous Greek state under Ottoman suzerainty, as stipulated in the [[Treaty of London (1827)|Treaty of London]]. Ottoman refusal to accept these terms led to the [[Battle of Navarino]], which effectively secured complete Greek independence. In 1827, the [[Third National Assembly at Troezen]] established the '''Hellenic State''' ({{lang|grc|Ἑλληνικὴ Πολιτεία}}) and selected Count [[Ioannis Kapodistrias]] as Governor of Greece. Therefore, this period is often called '''Governorate''' ({{lang-el|Κυβερνείο}}). After his arrival in Greece in January 1828, Kapodistrias actively tried to create a functional state and redress the problems of a war-ravaged country, but was soon embroiled in conflict with powerful local magnates and chieftains. [[File:Kapodistrias3.jpg|thumb|left|[[Ioannis Kapodistrias]] as Governor of Greece (Lithography, L. Nikiadis)]] Kapodistrias was assassinated by political rivals in 1831, plunging the country into renewed civil strife. He was succeeded by his brother [[Augustinos Kapodistrias|Augustinos]], who was forced to resign after six months. The [[Fifth National Assembly at Nafplion]] drafted a new royal constitution, while the three "Protecting Powers" ([[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Great Britain]], [[July Monarchy|France]] and [[Russian Empire|Russia]]) intervened, declaring Greece a Kingdom in the [[London Conference of 1832]], with the Bavarian Prince [[Otto of Greece|Otto of Wittelsbach]] as king. ==Heads of State== *[[Prince Alexander Mavrocordatos|Alexandros Mavrocordatos]] (January 13, 1822 – May 10, 1823) *[[Petros Mavromichalis]] (May 10, 1823 – December 31, 1823) *[[Georgios Kountouriotis]] (December 31, 1823 – April 26, 1826) *[[Andreas Zaimis]] (April 26, 1826 – April 14, 1827) *[[Ioannis Kapodistrias]] (May, 1827 – 27 September 1831) *[[Augustinos Kapodistrias]] (October 9, 1831 – March 23, 1832) *Governmental Commission (1832 – 1833) ==See also== * [[History of the Hellenic Republic]] ==External links== {{portalbar|Greece}} * [http://www.hellenicparliament.gr/en/Vouli-ton-Ellinon/To-Politevma/Syntagmatiki-Istoria/ Hellenic Parliament - Constitutional History of Greece] {{Greek War of Independence|state=collapsed}} {{Ioannis Kapodistrias}} {{coord|37.5702|N|22.8057|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hellenic Republic, First}} [[Category:States and territories established in 1822]] [[Category:States and territories disestablished in 1832]] [[Category:Greek War of Independence|First Hellenic Republic]] [[Category:Former republics|Greece]] [[Category:Provisional governments]] [[Category:Political history of Greece]] [[Category:1822 establishments in Greece]] [[Category:1832 disestablishments in Greece]]

[[File:Galician slaughter in 1846.PNG|thumb|350px|right|"Rzeź galicyjska" by [[Jan Lewicki]] (1795–1871)]] [[File:Galician slaughter - General Map.PNG|thumb|350px|right|Theatre of the Galician [[Peasant movement|peasant war]] of 1846]] The '''Galician Slaughter''',<ref name="Janowski2004">{{cite book|author=Maciej Janowski|title=Polish Liberal Thought Before 1918|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ieF7NYaEqQYC&pg=PA99|accessdate=3 November 2012|year=2004|publisher=Central European University Press|isbn=978-963-9241-18-3|page=99}}</ref> also known as the '''[[peasant uprising|Peasant Uprising]] of 1846'''<ref name="Nance2008">{{cite book|author=Agnieszka Barbara Nance|title=Literary and Cultural Images of a Nation Without a State: The Case of Nineteenth-Century Poland|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I9S5g8mpgj0C&pg=PA62|accessdate=3 November 2012|year=2008|publisher=Peter Lang|isbn=978-0-8204-7866-1|pages=62–64}}</ref> or the '''Szela uprising'''<ref name=Narkiewicz>{{cite book|author=Olga A. Narkiewicz|title=The Green Flag: Polish Populist Politics, 1867–1970|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Mn4OAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA19|accessdate=3 November 2012|year=1976|publisher=Croom Helm|isbn=978-0-87471-824-9|pages=18–19}}</ref> ({{lang-de|Galizischer Bauernaufstand}}; {{lang-pl|Rzeź galicyjska}} or ''Rabacja galicyjska''), was a two-month uprising of [[Galicia (Eastern Europe)|Galician]]{{Ref_label|a|a|none}} [[peasants]] that led to the suppression of the [[szlachta]] uprising ([[Kraków Uprising]]) and the massacre of szlachta in [[Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria|Galicia]] in the [[Austrian partition]] in early 1846. The uprising, which lasted from February to March, primarily affected the lands around the town of [[Tarnów]].<ref name=pwn>{{pl icon}} [http://encyklopedia.pwn.pl/haslo.php?id=3965088 rabacja galicyjska] in [[Internetowa encyklopedia PWN]]</ref>
It was a revolt against [[serfdom]], directed against manorial property and oppression (for example, the manorial prisons);<ref name=bidjef>{{cite book|author1=Robert Bideleux|author2=Ian Jeffries|title=A History of Eastern Europe: Crisis and Change|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PTB0gn_qwTcC|accessdate=4 April 2013|date=3 September 2007|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-203-01889-7|pages=295–296}}</ref> Galician peasants killed about 1,000 noblemen and destroyed about 500 manors.<ref name=pwn/><ref>{{cite book|author=[[Iván T. Berend]] |title=History Derailed: Central and Eastern Europe in the Long Nineteenth Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tlKbYdjLZ0wC&pg=RA1-PA212|accessdate=3 November 2012|date=17 June 2003|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-23299-0|page=212}}</ref> The Austrian government used the uprising to decimate nationalist Polish nobles, who were organizing an uprising against Austria.<ref name=pwn/>
==Background== In the semi-autonomous [[Free City of Kraków]], patriotic Polish intellectuals and nobles (szlachta) had made plans for a [[Greater Poland Uprising (1846)|general uprising in partitioned Poland]], intending to reestablish an independent Poland.<ref name="Dowe2001-171-172"/><ref name="Dowe2001-173"/> A similar uprising of nobility was planned in [[Poznań]], but police quickly caught the ringleaders.<ref name="Dowe2001-173"/><ref name="MagocsiSedlar1974-133">{{cite book|author1=Paul Robert Magocsi|author2=Jean W. Sedlar|author3=Robert A. Kann|author4=Charles Jevich |author5=Joseph Rothschild|title=A History of East Central Europe: The lands of partitioned Poland, 1795-1918|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TVMmGKsbWJ4C&pg=PA133|accessdate=4 April 2013|year=1974|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=978-0-295-80361-6|page=133}}</ref> The [[Kraków Uprising]] began on the night of February 20, and initially met with limited successes.<ref name="Dowe2001-171-172"/><ref name="LERSKI1996-90"/><ref name="Dowe2001-174"/>
In the meantime, the recent poor harvests resulted in significant unrest among the local peasantry.<ref name="Jezierski2003">{{cite book|author=Andrzej Jezierski|title=Historia Gospodarcza Polski|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_75stIZO7WAC&pg=PA143|accessdate=4 April 2013|year=2003|publisher=Key Text Wydawnictwo|isbn=978-83-87251-71-0|pages=143–144}}</ref>
==Uprising== The Kraków uprising was a spark that ignited the peasants' rebellion.<ref name=bidjef/> The insurgent nobles made appeals to the peasants, reminding them of the popular hero [[Tadeusz Kościuszko]] and promising an end to serfdom.<ref name="LERSKI1996-90"/><ref name="MagocsiSedlar1974-134">{{cite book|author1=Paul Robert Magocsi|author2=Jean W. Sedlar|author3=Robert A. Kann|author4=Charles Jevich |author5=Joseph Rothschild|title=A History of East Central Europe: The lands of partitioned Poland, 1795–1918|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TVMmGKsbWJ4C&pg=PA133|accessdate=4 April 2013|year=1974|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=978-0-295-80361-6|page=134}}</ref> Some peasants indeed sided with the nobles. Narkiewicz and Hahn, among others, note that the peasants around Kraków, many of whom remembered the promises made by Kościuszko and [[kosynierzy|peasant soldiers]] who fought beside him, were sympathetic to the noble insurgents.<ref name=Narkiewicz/><ref name="Dowe2001-171-172"/> Another account is of the peasants in [[Chochołów, Lesser Poland Voivodeship|Chochołów]], who gathered under a Polish flag and fought the Austrians.<ref name="Nance2008"/><ref name="Wandycz1975"/>
Most sources agree that the Austrians encouraged the peasants to revolt.<ref name="Nance2008"/><ref name="Jezierski2003"/><ref name="MagocsiSedlar1974-134"/><ref name="LukowskiZawadzki2006">{{cite book|author1=Jerzy Lukowski|author2=Hubert Zawadzki|title=A Concise History of Poland|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HMylRh-wHWEC&pg=PA170|accessdate=4 April 2013|date=6 July 2006|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-85332-3|page=170}}</ref> A number of sources point to the actions of the Austrian [[Tarnów]] administration, in particular an official identified as the District Officer of [[Tarnów]], [[Johann Breindl von Wallerstein]].<ref name="Nance2008"/><ref name="Jezierski2003"/><ref name="Wandycz1975"/><ref name="Davies2005">{{cite book|author=Norman Davies|title=God's Playground A History of Poland: Volume II: 1795 to the Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9Tbed6iMNLEC&pg=PA108|accessdate=4 April 2013|date=24 February 2005|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-925340-1|pages=108–109}}</ref> Wallerstein reached out to peasant leader [[Jakub Szela]].<ref name="Nance2008"/><ref name="Davies2005"/> Serfs were promised the end of their feudal duties if they helped to put down the insurgent Polish noblemen, and were also paid in money and salt for the heads of nobles.<ref name="Nance2008"/><ref name="Davies2005"/> Hahn notes "it is generally accepted as proven that the Austrian authorities deliberately exploited peasant dissatisfaction in order to suppress the national uprising."<ref name="Dowe2001-173"/><ref name="Dowe2001-174"/> Magosci et al. write that "most contemporaries condemned the Austrian authorities for their perfidious use of the peasantry for counter-revolutionary aims."<ref name="Wandycz1975"/>
It was ironic, as historian [[Eric Hobsbawm]] has noted, that the peasants turned their anger on the revolutionaries, whose ideals also included improvement of the peasants' situation.<ref name="Anderson2006">{{cite book|author=Benedict Anderson|title=Imagined Communities: Reflections on the Origin and Spread of Nationalism (New Edition)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nQ9jXXJV-vgC&pg=PA82|accessdate=3 April 2013|date=17 November 2006|publisher=Verso|isbn=978-1-84467-086-4|page=82}}</ref> The progressive ideals of the Polish insurgents{{please clarify|date=October 2018}} were praised, among others, by [[Karl Marx]], who called it a "deeply democratic movement that aimed at land reform and other pressing social questions".<ref name="Anderson2010">{{cite book|author=Kevin B. Anderson|title=Marx at the Margins: On Nationalism, Ethnicity, and Non-Western Societies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OSsCocp6p8YC&pg=PA77|accessdate=3 April 2013|date=15 May 2010|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-01984-0|pages=77–78}}</ref> As noted by several historians, the peasants were not so much acting out of loyalty to the Austrians, as revolting against the oppressive feudal system, of which the Polish nobles were prime representatives and beneficiaries in the Galician region.<ref name="Nance2008"/><ref name="Dowe2001-174"/><ref name="LukowskiZawadzki2006"/> Wolff takes a different stance here, by noting that it is likely that the Austrian authorities held greater sway with the peasants, who saw improvement in their living conditions in the recent decades, which they associated with the new Austrian rule.<ref name="Wolff2012"/>
[[File:Galicyjscy chłopi składają głowy swoich ofiar.jpg|thumb|Peasants were paid in money and salt for the heads of nobles]] Bideleux and Jeffries (2007) are among the dissenters to that view, citing Alan Sked's 1989 research that contends that "the Habsburg authorities – despite later chargers of connivance – knew nothing about what was going on and were appalled at the results of the blood-lust."<ref name=bidjef/> Hahn notes that during the events of 1846 "the Austrian bureaucracy played a dubious role that has not been completely explained, down to the present day."<ref name="Dowe2001-171-172"/>
The peasants also aided the Austrian army in defeating the insurgents at the [[battle of Gdów]].<ref name="MagocsiSedlar1974-134"/><ref name="Deck-partyka2006">{{cite book|author=Alicja Deck-partyka|title=Poland: A Unique Country & Its People|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3C8JR8Gv3AkC&pg=PA40|accessdate=3 April 2013|date=30 June 2006|publisher=AuthorHouse|isbn=978-1-4678-0448-6|pages=40–41}}</ref><ref name="Rusinowa1986">{{cite book|author=Izabella Rusinowa|title=Polska w latach 1795–1864: wybór tekstów źródłowych do nauczania historii|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PWZpAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=4 April 2013|year=1986|publisher=Wydawn. Szkolne i Pedagog.|isbn=978-83-02-02790-1|page=198}}</ref>
Peasants attacked the manor houses of the rebel noble leaders as well as of suspected rebel nobles and killed many hundreds of the estate owners and their families; about 90% of the [[dwór|manor houses]] in the Tarnów region are estimated to have been destroyed.<ref name="Wandycz1975">{{cite book|last=Wandycz|first=Piotr S.|authorlink=Piotr S. Wandycz|title=The Lands of Partitioned Poland, 1795–1918|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9dUHCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA135|accessdate=9 September 2016|year=1975|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=978-0-295-80361-6|page=135}}</ref> At least 470 manor houses were destroyed.<ref name="Jezierski2003"/> Estimates of the number of lives lost by Polish estate owners and officials range from 1,000 to 2,000.<ref name="MagocsiSedlar1974-133"/> Jezierski notes that most of the victims were not nobles (he estimates those constituted maybe about 200 of the fatalities) but their direct employees.<ref name="Jezierski2003"/> Most of the victims had no direct involvement with the Polish insurgents other than being a part of the same social class.<ref name="Dowe2001-173"/> (Davies also notes that near [[Bochnia]], Austrian officials were attacked by overzealous peasantry.<ref name="Davies2005"/>) Bideleux and Jeffries discuss the total number of victims noting that "more than two thousand lives were lost on both sides", which suggests that most of the victims were from among the Polish nobility.<ref name=bidjef/>
The uprising was eventually put down by Austrian troops. Accounts of the pacification vary. Bideleux and Jeffries note it was "brutally put down by the Austrian troops".<ref name=bidjef/> Jezierski notes the use of [[flagellation]] by the authorities.<ref name="Jezierski2003"/> Nance describes the arrest and exile of the anti-Austrian peasants in Chochołów.<ref name="Nance2008"/> Magocsi et al. note that the peasants were punished by being forced to resume their feudal obligations, while their leader, Szela, received a medal and a land grant.<ref name="Wandycz1975"/><ref name="Davies2005"/>
==Legacy== [[Serfdom]], with [[corvée]] labor, existed in Galicia until 1848, and the 1846 massacre of Polish szlachta is credited with helping to bring on its demise.<ref name="Jezierski2003"/><ref name="Davies2005"/><ref name="WHITEMurphy2001-170">{{cite book|author1=Harry White|author2=Michael Murphy|title=Musical Constructions of Nationalism: Essays on the History and Ideology of European Musical Culture, 1800-1945|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wssMMxN4F1cC&pg=PA164|accessdate=4 April 2013|year=2001|publisher=Cork University Press|isbn=978-1-85918-153-9|page=170}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|publisher=H.M. Stationery Office, London, via World Digital Library|last=Prothero|first=G. W.|authorlink=George Walter Prothero|title=Austrian Poland|series=Peace handbooks|accessdate=2014-06-05|date=1920|pages=20-21|url=http://www.wdl.org/en/item/9175/view/1/32/}}</ref>
The destruction of crops during the hostilities was one of the reasons for the ensuing [[famine]].<ref name="Stauter-Halsted2005">{{cite book|author=Keely Stauter-Halsted|title=The Nation In The Village: The Genesis Of Peasant National Identity In Austrian Poland, 1848-1914|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g7Nwn-WzLC4C&pg=PA26|accessdate=4 April 2013|date=28 February 2005|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=978-0-8014-8996-9|page=26}}</ref>
For the Polish nobles and reformers, this event was a lesson that class lines are a powerful force, and that peasants cannot be expected to support a cause of independent Poland without education and reform.<ref name="Nance2008"/><ref name="Dowe2001-173"/>
Soon after the uprising was put down, the [[Republic of Cracow]] was abolished and incorporated into [[Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria|Galicia]].<ref name="Nance2008"/>
The massacre of the gentry in 1846 was the historical memory that haunted [[Stanisław Wyspiański]]'s play ''[[The Wedding (1901 play)|The Wedding]]''.<ref name="Wolff2012-390">{{cite book|author=Larry Wolff|title=The Idea of Galicia: History and Fantasy in Habsburg Political Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tgjQYHn7BTkC&pg=PA390|accessdate=4 April 2013|date=9 January 2012|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0-8047-7429-1|page=390}}</ref> The uprising was also described in the stories "Der Kreisphysikus" and "Jacob Szela" by [[Marie von Ebner-Eschenbach]].<ref name="Nance2008"/>
== See also == * [[Revolutions of 1848]]
==Notes== '''a''' {{Note_label|a|a|none}} The nationality of the peasants is a complex issue. A number of sources describe them as Polish.<ref>"Austriacy wraz z polskimi chłopami zadali powstańcom klęskę pod [[Gdów|Gdowem]] 26 lutego 1846, zaś chłopi wymordowali wielu powstańców. Historia Polski. by [[Michał Tymowski]], [[Jan Kieniewicz]], [[Jerzy Holzer]]. Warszawa. 1990. str. 234</ref> Hahn notes that the peasants in the region affected by the uprising were not [[Ruthenians|Ruthenian]], but rather "Polish speaking Catholics".<ref name="Dowe2001-171-172"/> Others, however, note that the peasants had little national identity and considered themselves [[Masurians]]; to quote one of the peasants as late as end of World War I: "The older peasants called themselves Masurians, and their speech Masurian ... I myself did not know that I was a Pole till I began to read books and papers, and I fancy that other villagers came to be aware of the national attachment in much the same way."<ref name="WHITEMurphy2001-164">{{cite book|author1=Harry White|author2=Michael Murphy|title=Musical Constructions of Nationalism: Essays on the History and Ideology of European Musical Culture, 1800–1945|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wssMMxN4F1cC&pg=PA164|accessdate=4 April 2013|year=2001|publisher=Cork University Press|isbn=978-1-85918-153-9|page=164}}</ref> In turn Wolff prefers to talk of "Galician peasants".<ref name="Wolff2012">{{cite book|author=Larry Wolff|title=The Idea of Galicia: History and Fantasy in Habsburg Political Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tgjQYHn7BTkC&pg=PA179|accessdate=3 April 2013|date=9 January 2012|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0-8047-7429-1|pages=179–182}}</ref>
