[[File:Zhuang woman in Guilin, China.jpg|thumb|alt=Woman selling textiles at an outdoor market|[[Zhuang people|Zhuang]] woman in [[Guilin]]]] [[China]] was a [[Socialist economy with Chinese characteristics|socialist]] [[planned economy]] which promoted [[gender equality]] before 1978. After embarking on economic reforms in the 1990s and early 2000s, gender inequality in the Chinese [[labour markets]] emerged as significant economic and [[social issue]]s.
On a global scale, '''gender inequality in China''' is relatively slight. In 2014, China ranked 40th out of 187 countries on the [[United Nations Development Programme]]'s [[Gender Inequality Index]] (GII). Among the GII components, China's [[maternal mortality ratio]] was 32 out of 100,000 live births. In education 58.7 percent of women age 25 and older had completed [[secondary education]], while the counterpart statistic for men was 71.9 percent. Women's [[labour force]] participation rate was 63.9 percent (compared to 78.3 percent for men), and women held 23.6 percent of seats in the [[National People's Congress]].<ref name="GII">{{cite web|title=Gender Inequality Index|url=http://hdr.undp.org/en/composite/GII|website=United Nations Development Programme|accessdate=25 October 2016}}</ref> {{Women in society sidebar}}
=={{anchor|Before the Chinese Revolution of 1949}}Before the 1949 revolution== Before the 1949 [[Maoism|Maoist]] revolution, women were generally restricted to the traditional gender roles of wives, [[Concubinage|concubines]], or [[Prostitution|prostitutes]].<ref name="fulton"/> Female oppression stemmed partly from [[Confucianism|Confucian]] beliefs about gender roles in society (such as [[filial piety]]), ideas which remain influential.<ref name="li">{{cite journal|last1=Li|first1=Chenyang|date=December 2002|title=Confucianism and Feminist Concerns: Overcoming the Confucian "Gender Complex"|journal=Journal of Chinese Philosophy}}</ref> Wives were expected to be subservient to their husbands, [[kowtow]]ing to their husbands.<ref name="fulton"/> Concubines had less choice than married women, and were kept as mistresses by men for sexual services or to produce children.<ref name="fulton"/> Prostitution frequently resulted from women being sold into brothels by their parents.<ref name="fulton"/> Legal during the [[Qing dynasty|Qing Dynasty]], there were few laws regulating prostitution;<ref name="ruskola"/> as a result, prostitutes were similar to slaves and lacked [[Natural and legal rights|legal rights]].<ref name="ruskola"/>
Marriage was defined loosely and encompassed wives, concubines, and slaves.<ref name="ruskola" /> Men were free to pursue sex from women in any of these three categories of "extended family".<ref name="ruskola" /> Women were prohibited from having sex with family slaves, a crime punishable by [[decapitation]].<ref name="ruskola" /> Men were frequently [[Polygamy|polygamous]] (allowed one wife and an unlimited number of concubines), but women were permitted only one husband.<ref name="ruskola" /> This relationship between men and women in the household illustrated the power held by men in the family and their greater freedom compared with women.<ref name="fulton">{{cite web|last1=Fulton|first1=Jessica|title=Holding up Half the Heavens: The Effect of Communist Rule on China's Women|url=https://www.iusb.edu/ugr-journal/static/2000/pdf/fulton.pdf|accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref><ref name="ruskola">{{cite journal|last1=Ruskola|first1=Teemu|title=Law, Sexual Morality, and Gender Equality in Qing and Communist China|journal=The Yale Law Journal|date=June 1994|volume=103|issue=8|pages=2531–2565|doi=10.2307/797055|jstor=797055}}</ref> Women, for example, would generally lose social standing due to an extramarital affair.<ref name="ruskola" /> However, [[Qing dynasty|Qing laws]] punished both parties equally for premarital sex.<ref name="ruskola" />
=== {{anchor|Foot Binding}}Foot binding === A noted repressive practice was [[foot binding]].<ref name="li" /> Foot binding originated during the [[Song dynasty|Song Dynasty]], and was practiced by the wealthiest members of society in the 11th century. Over time, the practice increased and spread to the peasantry.<ref name="fulton" /> Foot binding was intended to differentiate between upper and lower classes; it was considered attractive,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ancient.eu/Foot-Binding/|title=Foot-Binding|work=Ancient History Encyclopedia|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref> with bound feet known as "golden lotuses".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/ptop/alabaster/A1155872|title=BBC Chinese Foot Binding|website=www.bbc.co.uk|access-date=2016-11-03}}</ref>
It aimed to limit the growth of girls' feet, and began at age three. Foot binding eventually resulted in the arch of the foot becoming so angled that a woman was in constant pain and had limited ability to walk.<ref name="fulton" /> Foot binding subordinated women to men in a number of respects. It was an essential component of marriage eligibility, since women often bound their feet to increase their chance of finding a better marriage partner.<ref name="binding">{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=8966942|title=Painful Memories for China's Footbinding Survivors|newspaper=NPR.org|access-date=2016-11-03}}</ref> Men used foot binding to force women to be dependent; due to pain associated with walking, women were limited to household activities.<ref name="fulton" /><ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Ko|first=Dorothy|date=1997|title=The Body as Attire: The Shifting Meanings of Footbinding in Seventeenth-Century China|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/363238/summary|journal=Journal of Women's History|language=en|volume=8|issue=4|pages=8–27|doi=10.1353/jowh.2010.0171|issn=1527-2036}}</ref> Women with bound feet had considerable difficulty carrying out simple tasks (such as standing up from a chair without assistance) and a lower functional reach than women with normal feet.<ref name=":3" /> Foot binding encouraged the sexual objectification of women, since it fulfilled men's sexual desires and fantasies.<ref name=":6" /> It reinforced the [[ideology]] that women were useful only in sexualized, sedentary roles to satisfy men's desires.<ref name=":6" />
Foot binding was such an established part of Chinese culture that the [[Kangxi Emperor|Emperor K'ang Hsi]] was unable to suppress the practice in 1650.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gamble|first=Sidney D.|title=The Disappearance of Foot-Binding in Tinghsien|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/pdfplus/10.1086/219351|journal=American Journal of Sociology|language=en|volume=49|issue=2|pages=181–183|doi=10.1086/219351|year=1943}}</ref> Widespread anti-foot binding sentiment began during the late 19th century, and gained in popularity until the practice was outlawed in 1912.<ref name="binding" /> In 1997, the feet of 38 percent of [[Beijing]] women over 80 years of age and 18 percent of women aged 70–79 were deformed by foot binding.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Cummings|first=S R|last2=Ling|first2=X|last3=Stone|first3=K|date=1997-10-01|title=Consequences of foot binding among older women in Beijing, China.|url=http://ajph.aphapublications.org/doi/abs/10.2105/AJPH.87.10.1677|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=87|issue=10|pages=1677–1679|doi=10.2105/AJPH.87.10.1677|issn=0090-0036|pmc=1381134}}</ref>
=== {{anchor|Women's Education}}Women's education === The purpose of women's education was to reinforce their subordinate status and ensure that they obeyed rules made by men. Women were taught social norms which restricted their rights and behavior.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gao|first=Xiongya|date=2003|title=Women Existing for Men: Confucianism and Social Injustice against Women in China|journal=Interdisciplinary Topics in Race, Gender, and Class|volume=10|pages=114–125|jstor=41675091}}</ref> Only middle-class and wealthier women would receive an education, indicating a family's superiority. Women were educated at home by teachers who followed social norms. In the [[Eastern Han dynasty|Eastern Han Dynasty]], four books were used for women's education: ''Nü sishu'' (including ''Nüjie'') by [[Ban Zhao]], ''Nü lunyu'' by Song Ruoxin, ''Nüxun'' by [[Empress Xiaochengren|Empress Renxiao]], and ''Nüfan jielu'' by Ms. Liu.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tang|first=Catherine So-Kum|last2=Lai|first2=Beatrice Pui-Yee|date=February 2008|title=A review of empirical literature on the prevalence and risk markers of male-on-female intimate partner violence in contemporary China, 1987–2006|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1359178907000596|journal=Aggression and Violent Behavior|volume=13|pages=1|via=|doi=10.1016/j.avb.2007.06.001}}</ref> These books reinforced norms which harmed women and restricted their daily activities. The three obediences and four virtues which were adopted by many women are part of ''Nüjie''. The three obediences were "obey father before marriage", "obey husband during marriage" and "obey sons during widowhood", illustrating the subordination of women to men throughout their lives. The four virtues were "female virtues", "female words", "female appearance" and "female work", designed to fulfill the needs of men and society. Women's desires and needs were trivialized, and education became a tool to maintain male control of women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theworldofchinese.com/2015/10/ancient-chinas-virtuous-women/|title=Ancient China’s "Virtuous" Women|last=Sun|first=Jiahui|date=20 October 2015|website=|access-date=27 February 2018}}</ref>
A woman's personality was also restricted by this education. Women were taught to be weak and subordinate, respecting the men who dominated them. The physical differences between men and women as well were emphasized; men were seen as yin, and women were seen as yang. [[Yin and yang]] are the opposite of each other, and women were not allowed to physically interact with men outside of marriage. Women (as yang) were considered a negative element, reinforcing their inferior status, and were sometimes forbidden from leaving their room to demonstrate their loyalty. Obedience to men and elder relatives was the essential element of women's education. Women were powerless to resist, since society would not accept women who challenged men. As a socializing agent, women's education played an important role in shaping their image and maintaining their subordinate status for many dynasties.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chan|first=Susan|last2=Leong|first2=Cynthia W.|date=7 July 2016|title=Chinese Families in Transition: Cultural Conflicts and Adjustment Problems|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1007/BF02087760|journal=Journal of Social Distress and the Homeless|volume=3|issue=3|pages=263–281|via=|doi=10.1007/BF02087760}}</ref>
=={{anchor|The Mao era}}Mao era== During the planned-economy era of (1949-1978, also known as the [[Mao Zedong]] era), the [[Communist Party of China|Communist Party]] sought to make [[Chinese women]] legally and socially equal to men.<ref name=X>{{cite journal|last1=Li|first1=Xiaojiang|title=Where do we go During 50 Years?--A Review on Chinese Women's Liberation and Development Processes|journal=Zhejiang Academic Journal|date=2000|volume=2}}</ref> The Communist government attempted to challenge Confucian beliefs,<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Bauer, Feng, Riley, Xiaohua|first=|date=1992|title=Gender Inequality in Urban China: Education and Employment|url=|journal=Modern China|volume=18|issue=3|pages=333–370|doi=10.1177/009770049201800304|via=}}</ref> and one of its main goals was to improve the social position of women by promoting their entry into the [[labour force]].<ref name=":0" /> [[Constitution of the People's Republic of China|The Constitution of the People's Republic of China]], which was enacted in 1954, stated that women and men should have equal rights. To promote gender equality, the Communist Party promoted the slogan "Women hold up half the sky" to illustrate the importance of women to China's economic success.<ref name="Bulger">{{cite journal|last1=Bulger|first1=Christine M.|title=Fighting Gender Discrimination in the Chinese Workplace|journal=Boston College Third World Journal|date=1 April 2000|volume=20|issue=2|pages=345–391}}</ref> The party and the government implemented policies ensuring equal pay for equal work and [[equal opportunity]] for men and women.<ref name="Z">{{cite journal|last1=Wu|first1=Zhongzhe|title=Gender Inequalities of the Labor Market During Market Transistion|journal=Economic Theory and Policy Research|date=2009|volume=2}}</ref>
In practice, however, wage inequality still existed during this era due to occupational and industrial segregation by gender.<ref name=L>{{cite journal|last1=Liu|first1=Jieyu|title=Gender Dynamics and Redundancy in Urban China|journal=Feminist Economics|date=July 2007|volume=13|issue=3–4|pages=125–158|doi=10.1080/13545700701445322}}</ref> Enterprises typically divided their jobs into two groups (primary and secondary); men were more likely to be given primary jobs, and women secondary jobs.<ref name=Z /> While women were entering the labour market, they were still expected to look after their homes and families. As a result, women were said to bear "a double burden" of work during the Mao era.<ref name="zhangsun">{{cite book|last1=Zhang|first1=Jun|last2=Peidong|first2=Sun|title=Wives, Husbands, and Lovers: Marriage and Sexuality in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Urban China|date=2014|publisher=Stanford University Press|pages=118–144}}</ref>
=== State feminism === [[State feminism]] refers to the state's support of women's equality in the public and work sectors through legislation, often progressive state laws to ensure gender equality.<ref name=":9">Yang, Mayfair Mei-hui (1999). Spaces of their own : women's public sphere in transnational China. University of Minnesota Press, Minneapolis</ref> This state-supported feminism promoted employment opportunities for women in the public sector and provided benefits such as [[Parental leave|maternity leave]] and [[Child care|day care]] to female workers. State feminism also enforced laws prohibiting [[polygamy]], the buying and selling of women, [[arranged marriage]] and prostitution.<ref name=":9" />
Yang stated in her article, "From Gender Erasure to Gender Difference", that state feminism during the Mao era liberated "women from the traditional kinship patriarchy, but although women were catapulted into the public sphere of labour and politics, the feminist agenda was forgotten with the decline of gender salience and women's transformation into state subjects in a new masculine state order".<ref name=":9" /> According to Lisa Rofel, an American anthropologist studying [[feminism]] and [[gender studies]], "The status of unfortunate widows (and their daughters) of poor families changed dramatically from 'broken shoes' to 'labour models' after 1949".<ref>Rofel, L. (2009). Other modernities: gendered yearnings in China after socialism. Berkeley: University of California Press.</ref> Although state feminism provided some legal protection to women, it did not achieve gender equality. Gail Hershatter agreed: "The communist revolution didn't change the work women did. Women had always worked. What the revolution changed is the work environment and the social interpretation of working outside of familial context."<ref>Hershatter, G.(2011). The Gender of Memory: Rural Women and China’s Collective Past. Berkeley: University of California Press. Retrieved February 26, 2018, from Project MUSE database.</ref>
=={{anchor|The Post-Mao era}}Post-Mao era== === {{anchor|Economic reforms and the labour market}}Economic reforms and labour market === Changing employment policy was a major part of China's reforms after the Mao era.<ref name="S">{{cite journal|last1=Liu|first1=Shejian|title=Review and Reflection on China's Employment System Three Decades Reform|journal=Social Sciences|date=2008|volume=3}}</ref> Under Mao China formed the Tong Bao Tong Pei employment system, a centralised system which created government-guaranteed jobs.<ref name="S" /> Due to widespread unemployment after the [[Cultural Revolution]], the Communist Party and the government phased out guaranteed employment and reformed the employment system as part of larger economic changes.<ref name="S" />
Reform took place in three stages.<ref name=S /> During the first stage (1978–1991), the existing framework was adapted: maintaining planned employment as the primary form of employment and adding a two-track system permitting government and private-sector employment.<ref name=S /> In the second stage (1992–2001), additional reforms continued to promote the market-oriented employment system while maintaining a degree of planned employment.<ref name=S /> In the third stage (after 2001), the reform process was accelerated to generate a market-oriented employment system in which private-sector employment was primary.<ref name=S /> Market reforms took China away from central economic planning and towards a system based on capitalist market mechanisms.<ref name="osburg">{{cite book|last1=Osburg|first1=John|title=Anxious Wealth|date=2013|publisher=Stanford University Press}}</ref>
Although women gained significantly greater opportunities for work under the economic reform, they have borne a disproportionate share of its costs.<ref>Gale,Summerfield . 1994. ''Economic Reform and the Employment of Chinese Women.'' Journal of Economic Issues 28(3): 715 – 32.</ref><ref name="Gaetano">{{cite book|last1=Gaetano|first1=Arianne|title=Out to Work|date=2015|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press}}</ref> China's market-oriented economic reforms undermined workplace gender equality by using migrant women as a cheap, flexible labour force.<ref name="Gaetano"/> Migrant women make up a large proportion of factory workers, maids, and domestic workers, jobs which are prone to exploitation due to a lack of public scrutiny.<ref name="Gaetano"/> However, migrant women are essential to the success of China's free-market economy; without their inexpensive labour, the country could not compete successfully in the global manufacturing market.<ref name="Gaetano"/> Lacking strict government regulations protecting women's rights (partially due to the degree of corruption in China), gender inequality in thelabouur market continues to be an issue plaguing the country's free [[market system]].<ref name="osburg"/><ref name="Gaetano"/>
Since the economic reforms, the average real earnings of male professional workers have grown by 350 percent.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} Although women have gained working opportunities, the unparalleled growth in male salaries have widened the gender wage gap. The greatest ( and broadest) increases in the wage gap occurred during the late 1990s, as the labour market shifted from an administratively-regulated wage system to a market-oriented one.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2013-02-01|title=Economic reform, education expansion, and earnings inequality for urban males in China, 1988–2009|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0147596712000376|journal=Journal of Comparative Economics|language=en|volume=41|issue=1|pages=227–244|doi=10.1016/j.jce.2012.04.004|issn=0147-5967 | last1 = Meng | first1 = Xin | last2 = Shen | first2 = Kailing | last3 = Xue | first3 = Sen}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|date=2001-03-01|title=The Anatomy of Rising Earnings Inequality in Urban China|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0147596700917001|journal=Journal of Comparative Economics|language=en|volume=29|issue=1|pages=118–135|doi=10.1006/jcec.2000.1700|issn=0147-5967 | last1 = Gustafsson | first1 = Björn | last2 = Shi | first2 = Li}}</ref>
=== {{anchor|One-Child Policy and Gender Disparity}}One-child policy and gender disparity === [[File:Women working in a silk factory in China.jpg|thumb|alt=Women working at sewing machines in a large room|Female workers in a Chinese silk factory]] Introduced in 1979, China's [[one-child policy]] set a limit on the number of children parents could have. Because parents preferred sons, the incidence of [[sex-selective abortion]]s and [[female infanticide]] substantially increased.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Zhu|first=Wei Xing|last2=Lu|first2=Li|last3=Hesketh|first3=Therese|date=2009-04-09|title=China’s excess males, sex selective abortion, and one child policy: analysis of data from 2005 national intercensus survey|url=https://www.bmj.com/content/338/bmj.b1211|journal=BMJ|language=en|volume=338|pages=b1211|doi=10.1136/bmj.b1211|issn=0959-8138|pmc=2667570|pmid=19359290}}</ref> This has led to male overpopulation in China; in 2005, men under age 20 outnumbered women by more than 32 million.<ref name=":10" />
=={{anchor|Inequality in the workplace}}Workplace inequality== {{update|section|date=September 2014}} === {{anchor|Earnings inequality}}Wage inequality === Gender-based wage [[Social stratification|stratification]] has become a major issue in post-reform China. A 2013 study found that women are paid 75.4 percent of what men are paid (an average of [[Renminbi|RMB]] 399 per month, compared to RMB 529 per month for men).<ref name="unequalpay">{{cite journal|last1=Xiu|first1=Lin|last2=Gunderson|first2=Morley|title=Gender Earnings Differences in China: Base Pay, Performance Pay, and Total Pay|journal=Contemporary Economic Policy|date=January 2013|volume=31|issue=1|pages=235–254|doi=10.1111/j.1465-7287.2011.00307.x}}</ref>
These statistics are in line with previous findings; a 1990 wage survey found that women earned 77.4 percent of male income in urban areas (RMB 149.6, compared to RMB 193.2 for men) and 81.4 percent of male income in rural areas (an annual average of RMB 1,235 for women and RMB 1,518 for men).<ref>Research group of Chinese Women's Social Status Survey, Chinese Women's Social Status Overview [M] Beijing: Chinese Women's Press, 1993 (In Chinese)</ref> These findings indicate that the income gap has not been closing in China, and wage inequality may be on the rise.<ref name="unequalpay" /> Two-thirds of this differential has been attributed to unequal pay for the same work.<ref name="unequalpay" /> Part of the difference results from higher-quality skills acquired by men through better educational opportunities, managerial positions, and previous work experience. Since women have limited opportunity to develop the education or skills necessary to obtain higher-level jobs, they are often paid less for their work;<ref name="unequalpay" /> female entrepreneurs are denied access to the networking opportunities of their male counterparts.<ref name="osburg" /> A number of factors have contributed to the rise in wage inequality in China.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Deng|first=Q.|last2=Li|first2=S.|date=2009-09-01|title=What Lies behind Rising Earnings Inequality in Urban China? Regression-based Decompositions|url=https://academic.oup.com/cesifo/article-abstract/55/3-4/598/299642|journal=CESifo Economic Studies|language=en|volume=55|issue=3–4|pages=598–623|doi=10.1093/cesifo/ifp015|issn=1610-241X}}</ref>
Educational background and profession have been identified as two main factors of an increased gender wage gap,<ref name=":7" /> and regional impacts have been recognized as a major cause of the increasing wage inequality.<ref name=":7" /> Women in the workplace still face discrimination, and are discouraged from applying for managerial and highly-paid jobs. The high end of most sectors is still male-dominated, and business events often include the sexual objectification of women. In Chinese business culture, deals and partnerships are made through evenings of banqueting, going to [[Karaoke box|KTV bars]] and drinking.<ref name="osburg" /> Female hostesses (and sometimes prostitutes) play an important role in the success of these gatherings, highlighting the the businessmen's masculinity.<ref name="osburg" /> Due to the sexualized nature of these events, female entrepreneurs are frequently discouraged from (or uncomfortable attending) these networking evenings.<ref name="osburg" /> As a result, businesswomen have less access to the networks of government officials, business partners, and underworld organizations which are crucial to entrepreneurial success in China.<ref name="osburg" />
A main factor in the [[Hong Kong]] gender wage gap is age. More men achieve superior positions in a job because women leave the job market earlier to take care of their family. Men remain in the job market longer, allowing for more more raises and better jobs. Women in their 30s earn 11 per cent less on average than their male counterparts, and the gap increases with age; women over 60 earn an average of [[Hong Kong dollar|HK$]]322,000, about half the HK$618,000 earned by men.<ref>https://www.scmp.com/business/companies/article/2149404/pay-gap-hong-kong-women-earn-more-men-20-only-half-when-they-turn</ref> Although the wage gap has narrowed, there is room for improvement. Gender-based wage inequality will be a major factor in pay decisions because of inclusion and diversity (I&D) programs; thirteen percent of [[Asia-Pacific]] employers have I&D programs.<ref>https://www.willistowerswatson.com/-/media/WTW/PDF/Insights/2018/09/five-keys-to-getting-compensation-right-wtw-ap.pdf</ref>
=== Occupational segregation === Feminization of [[informal sector]] employment and devaluation of female-dominated occupations are two new labor-market trends since China's economic reforms.<ref name="Xi">{{cite journal|last1=Tong|first1=Xin|title=Labor Markets, Gender and Social Stratification|journal=Collection of Women's Studies|date=September 2010|volume=5|issue=101}}</ref> A survey of seven provinces and eleven cities found that gender segregation increased in forty-four out of fifty-one examined occupations between 1985 and 2000,<ref name="Xi" /> and women were restricted from entering a larger number of professional occupations based on their gender.<ref name="Xi" /> They were barred from more white-collar jobs than blue-collar ones, demonstrating the difficulty women have in obtaining higher-level jobs.<ref name="H">{{cite journal|last1=Cai|first1=He|last2=Wu|first2=Xiaoping|title=Social Change and Occupational Gender Inequality|journal= Chinese Sociology & Anthropology|date=2005|volume=38|issue=4|doi=10.2753/CSA0009-4625380402|pages=37–53}}</ref> One impact of gendered jobs is lower wages for women, illustrated by the lower average incomes of female-dominated enterprises compared to male-dominated ones. During the early 1990s, an increase in the number of female employees in the sales and service industries was accompanied by a reduction in the average income of these sectors. Data from the same time period indicates an inverse relationship between the proportion of women employed at an institution and the average wage of the institution's employees.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Parish|first1=W.L.|last2=Busse|first2=S.|title=Gender and Work in Chinese Urban Life Under Reform: The Changing Social Contract|date=2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York}}</ref>
=== {{anchor|The beauty economy}}Beauty economy === The "beauty economy" refers to companies using attractive young women to increase profits.<ref name="osburg" /> The women used to promote goods and services are generally known as [[pink-collar worker]]s.<ref name="osburg" /> These women can be found at car shows and company booths at conventions, and in publishing, insurance, and real-estate development.<ref name="osburg" /> The beauty economy is a marked shift from Mao-era attitudes in which sexuality was subdued to promote gender equality.<ref name="jyang">{{cite journal|last1=Yang|first1=Jie|title=Nennu and Shunu: Gender, Body Politics, and the Beauty Economy in China|journal=Signs|date=2011|volume=36|issue=2|pages=333–357|doi=10.1086/655913}}</ref> In 21st-century China, sexuality is promoted in capitalist endeavors.<ref name="jyang" /> Although many women involved in the beauty economy hold relatively-mundane jobs, others are involved in legally-complicated endeavors as "grey women": mistresses and hostesses who cater to a rich clientele.<ref name="osburg" /> These women are sell their sexuality (sometimes including their bodies) as a consumable good in the capitalist economy.<ref name="osburg" /> The close relationship between hypersexualized grey women and the business world has made extramarital affairs common amongst Chinese businessmen.<ref name="osburg" /> This highly-publicized trend has created a new market for aging wives of products to remain youthful and (ideally) keep their husbands faithful.<ref name="jyang" /> In 2004, China had the world's eighth-largest cosmetics market in the world and Asia's second-largest.<ref name="jyang" /> The beauty economy has set high standards for physical appearance, encouraging women to consume youth-preserving products and promoting ageism.<ref name="jyang" />
=== Unemployment === During the [[state-owned enterprise]] (SOE) reforms of the late 1990s, women were laid off in greater numbers and received larger pay cuts than men.<ref name="Bulger" /> Female-dominated industries, such as textiles and other light industry, were affected greatly by the reforms and many women lost their jobs;<ref name="Z" /> employees in secondary jobs were laid off in greater numbers than those in primary jobs. Since women occupied a high proportion of secondary jobs, they were the first to be laid off during the economic downturn; women were also forced to retire at a younger age than men. The government-mandated retirement age for women was generally five years younger than that for men, but internal retirement ages (determined by individual enterprises) were even lower for women. Enterprises which laid off the most workers had performed poorly and were unable to survive in the new market economy; they also employed a larger proportion of women than men. When the companies went under, larger numbers of women than men were unemployed.<ref name="Z" />
=== {{anchor|Discriminatory hiring practices}}Hiring discrimination === During the market-oriented reforms, there was widespread evidence of employment discrimination in hiring.<ref name="Z" /> [[Sexism]] in recruitment takes two forms: explicit and hidden.<ref name="Z" /> Explicit gender discrimination refers to directly-stated restrictions on women in the recruitment process, and hidden discrimination occurs primarily in the preferential hiring of men. Contemporary China has three general types of gender-based hiring discrimination. Gender restrictions on careers and jobs create an environment where women are only welcomed into careers which match traditional female roles: primarily domestic, secretarial, or factory work.<ref name="Gaetano" /> Gender discrimination also affects women of reproductive age, who are frequently passed over due to a potential future loss of productivity resulting from pregnancy.<ref name="Bulger" /> [[Ageism]] affects many women, especially those working in the service industry (where youth is a key component of workplace success).<ref name="osburg" /> In this sector, women over age 30 are frequently denied jobs.<ref name="Z" /> Female job-seekers over age 40 are especially subject to ageism in most industries, despite being past child-bearing age.<ref name="Z" /> The age limit for men is more relaxed, usually 40 or 45 years of age.<ref name="Z" /> Although laws are in place to prevent hiring discrimination, there is little enforcement.<ref name="Gaetano" />
=== Impact of foreign direct investment on wages === [[Foreign direct investment]] (FDI) has significantly impacted employment in China. The number of employees hired by foreign direct investment enterprises in the country's urban areas increased steadily from 1985 to 2005; between 2002 and 2005, the number of employees hired by FDI enterprises in urban China increased by 5.95 million.<ref name="W">{{cite journal|last1=Gao|first1=Wenshu|title=Empirical Analysis on FDI's Impact on Employment in China|journal=International Symposium of Development and Innovation of the Service Industry|date=2007|pages=461–468}}</ref> FDI is mainly driven by China's low cost of labor. A considerable number of foreign-invested enterprises are based in labor-intensive industries such as the garment industry, electronics manufacturing, and the food and beverage processing industry.<ref name="W" />
FDI has disproportionately affected women, who frequently hold low-skill, low-paying factory jobs funded by foreign investment.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hu|first1=Hao|title=On the FDI's Impact on the Female Employment of Developing Countries|journal=Journal of the Shanghai Administration Institute|date=December 2003|volume=4|issue=4}}</ref> A 2000 study found that 62.1 percent of FDI-employed workers were female.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tan|first1=Shen|title=The Relationship between Foreign Enterprises, Local Governments and Women Migrant Workers in the Pearl River Delta|date=2000}}</ref> Wages by gender have been inconsistently affected by FDI, with pay equality in FDI industries increasing in 1995 and decreasing in 2005.<ref name="E">{{cite journal|last1=Braunstein|first1=Elissa|last2=Brenner|first2=Mark|title=Foreign Direct Investment and Gendered Wages in Urban China|journal=Feminist Economics|date=July 2007|volume=13|issue=3–4|pages=213–237|doi=10.1080/13545700701439432}}</ref> This shift may be caused by increased FDI investment in production, resulting in additional low-paying factory jobs which are predominantly filled by women.<ref name="E" />
=={{anchor|Confucianism and Gender}}Confucianism and gender== [[Confucianism]] provided a framework which judged individuals by their faithfulness and adherence to [[social norm]]s dictated by ancient customs.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jhLgdK84Ll8C&pg=PA407|title=Women, Culture, and Development: A Study of Human Capabilities|last=Nussbaum|first=Martha C.|last2=Glover|first2=Jonathan|date=1995-11-30|publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn=9780191521751|language=en}}</ref> Men were evaluated according to how well they fulfilled their [[social position]]s as husbands, fathers, sons or servants. Correspondingly, women were valued based on their conduct as wives, mothers and daughters.<ref name=":2" /> Mainly assigned household activities, women were considered less important and therefore inferior.<ref name=":2" />
During the late 12th century, [[Neo-Confucianism|neo-Confucian]] scholar [[Zhu Xi]] advocated the "three bonds" between ruler and subject, father and son, and husband and wife.<ref name="li" /> Husbands were granted power over their wives through the Confucian emphasis on sexual differentiation as key to maintaining societal harmony.<ref name="li" /> While husbands ruled the "external world", women operated in the "internal world" by running the household; however, women lacked power in society.<ref name="li" /> Although women held executive power in the household, their influence rarely rivaled that of men in the public sphere.<ref name="li" /> Confucian values indicated, and reinforced, a clear hierarchy.<ref name=":0" /> Women were subordinate to men—particularly young women, who were on the lowest level of this hierarchy.<ref name=":0" />
In Confucian Chinese culture, women's identities were often oppressed; the deeply-rooted Confucian teachings which shaped Chinese culture and values reinforced a patriarchal family unit that devalued women. A daughter was seen as a temporary member of her father's side of the family, since she would leave the family at marriage. This notion of family abandonment is reflected in Magarey Wolf's statement in "Uterine Families and the Women's Community" that "when a young woman marries, her formal ties with the household of her father are severed ... that she, like the water, may never return".<ref>Wolf, Margery：1972 – Ch. 3: “Uterine Families and the Women’s Community.” In ''Women and the Family in Rural Taiwan.''Pp.32–42. Stanford: Stanford University Press.</ref> In Chinese Confucian society, a woman's identity is subordinated and she is barely recognized as a person.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patheos.com/library/confucianism/ethics-morality-community/gender-and-sexuality|title=Gender and Sexuality|last=Richey|first=Jeffrey|date=|website=patheos|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.womeninworldhistory.com/lesson3.html|title=Women and Confucianism|last=|first=|date=|website=women in world history|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== {{anchor|Confucian influences in contemporary China}}Influence in contemporary China === For Chinese women, discovering [[personhood]] and [[kinship]] is challenging because Confucian culture can be an obstacle. Confucianism highlights the ideal of ''"nan zhu wai, nu zhu nei"'' (男主外，女主内), reflecting female subordination by encouraging women to remain in the household while their husbands are the breadwinners in the outside world.<ref>Feng, X. (2013), Women's Work, Men's Work: Gender and Tourism among the Miao in Rural China. Anthropology Work Review, 34: 2–14.</ref> According to Wang's 2012 article, "Goodbye Career, Hello Housekeeping", "80 percent of husbands in China hope their wives will become full-time homemakers" to stabilize their marriage and take care of their families.<ref>Wang, F. (Ed.). (2012, November 16). Goodbye career, hello housekeeping. Retrieved February 07, 2018, from http://www.ecns.cn/2012/11-16/35765.shtml</ref> Under the Confucian influence, it has been the norm for women to quit their outside job to fulfill their obligations as wives while men remain in control outside the household and remain in their profession. It is rare in Chinese society to challenge the idea of women sacrificing their professional career, because Chinese society has a "relative[ly] ambiguous boundary between public and private spheres".<ref name=":4">Fei, Xiaotong 1992[1947] CH.1 “Special Characteristics of Rural Society.” &Ch.4: “ChaxuGeju: the Differential Mode of Association.” In ''From the Soil, the Foundations of Chinese Society: a Translation of Fei Jiaotong's Xiangtu Zhongguo, with an Introduction and Epilogue''. X. Fei, G.G. Hamilton, and Z. Wang, eds. Pp. 37–44 & 60–70. Berkeley: University of California Press.</ref> This ambiguity may be a vital obstacle to gender equality. A women's sense of self in Chinese society includes her husband, her inner circle and her family by marriage, broadening (and complicating) her definition of personhood. Women's dedication and sacrifices are justified by a societal norms and a Confucian culture which increase female subordination. According to Chinese [[anthropologist]] [[Fei Xiaotong]], "Sacrificing the family for one's own interests, or the lineage for the interests of one's household, is in reality a formula, with this formula, it is impossible to prove that someone is acting selfishly".<ref name=":8">Fei, Xiaotong 1992[1947] CH.1 “Special Characteristics of Rural Society.” &Ch.4: “ChaxuGeju: the Differential Mode of Association.” In ''From the Soil, the Foundations of Chinese Society: a Translation of Fei Jiaotong's Xiangtu Zhongguo, with an Introduction and Epilogue''. X. Fei, G.G. Hamilton, and Z. Wang, eds. Pp. 69. Berkeley: University of California Press.</ref> <en are in an advantageous position, since this differential mode of association legitimizes women's sacrifice of their professional career as a normal social pattern for the benefit of the family; a husband's preference for his wife to stay home while he keeps his career is not seen as selfishness. Male selfishness is justified by the differential mode of association which "drives out [[social consciousness]]".<ref name=":8" /> Wives who sacrifice their "lineage for the sake of [their] family, [they are actually projected as] performing a public duty".<ref name=":4" />
=={{anchor|Familial pressure and marriage}}Family pressure and marriage== Women face significant pressures from their families during their mid- to late twenties to quit working and get married. In rural northwestern China, some mothers still consider education less important for their daughters since they are expected to marry and leave home.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|date=2009-09-01|title=Family sources of educational gender inequality in rural China: A critical assessment|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0738059309000467|journal=International Journal of Educational Development|language=en|volume=29|issue=5|pages=474–486|doi=10.1016/j.ijedudev.2009.04.007|pmid=20161037|issn=0738-0593 | last1 = Hannum | first1 = Emily | last2 = Kong | first2 = Peggy | last3 = Zhang | first3 = Yuping | pmc=2753976}}</ref> There is an insignificant gender gap in educational investments in rural northwestern China, however, indicating progress in educational gender equality.<ref name=":1" /> Although work can be a way for women to postpone marriage, failure to marry is socially unacceptable for Chinese women.<ref name="Gaetano"/> Fewer Chinese women remain working past marriage, and those who do often struggle to balance work and familial expectations.<ref name="zhangsun"/> By relinquishing income generation to their husbands and staying home, many Chinese women lose autonomy and authority. Societal adherence to strict Confucian values about filial piety and women's obedience to men, intended to create hierarchies in the home which produce harmony in society, produces a patrilineal, patriarchal system which discourages gender equality.<ref name="Jackson">{{cite book|last1=Jackson|first1=Stevi|title=East Asia Sexualities: Modernity, Gender and New Sexual Cultures|date=2008|publisher=Zed Books|location=New York|pages=1–30}}</ref> Marriage pressures stem from Confucian values which promote the necessity for women to marry to continue the family lineage by bearing a son.<ref name="Jackson"/>
Family pressure has been, and continues to be, a main driving force of Chinese marriages. Although society has progressed from traditional values, heterosexual marriages remain the most socially-accepted form of union. This leads to struggles for LGBTQ marriages to be accepted, leading to contract or cooperative marriages (''hezuo hunyin'' or ''xingshi hunyin'').<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ASvWCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT5|title=Sex in China|last=Jeffreys|first=Elaine|date=2015-06-05|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-7456-8594-6|language=en}}</ref> Cooperative marriages are an extreme form of heterosexual pretence, typically consensual relationships between a lesbian (''lala'') and a gay man. Cooperative marriages are the result of strong family pressure to conform to societal expectations of a heterosexual marriage, underpinning the inequality of same-sex marriages.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wfcc4jjS5FoC&pg=PA73|title=Shanghai Lalas: Female Tongzhi Communities and Politics in Urban China|last=Kam|first=Lucetta Yip Lo|date=2012-11-01|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|isbn=978-988-8139-45-3|language=en}}</ref>
Further examples of family pressure in Chinese society are flash [[Marriage in modern China|marriages]]. A flash (or blitz) marriage is a union between partners who have known each other for less than a month. This form of union has become increasingly popular in China due to economic and social factors. Men and women perceive happiness as a result of stability in contemporary China, particularly in the relationship and family spheres.<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4nIqDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA59|title=Television and Dating in Contemporary China: Identities, Love and Intimacy|last=Yang|first=Chao|date=2017-06-29|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-981-10-3987-4|language=en}}</ref> However, financial stability and successful careers have also become predominant aspirations amongst young professionals.<ref name=":5" /> Young professionals (particularly women) are often still expected to marry at a relatively-young age, and if they fail to do so they are known as ''[[sheng nu]]'' (leftover women}.<ref name=":5" /> Strong family pressure reinforces this ideology, and the focus on career development often leads to less time for individual personal lives (resulting in flash marriages).<ref name=":5" />
=== "Surplus women" === Women who resist family pressure and do not marry by their late twenties risk being stigmatized as ''sheng nu'' (剩女, leftover women).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QarOjjKfseo&t=686s|title=From 'Iron Girls' to 'Leftovers' – Independent Women in China|last=Broadly|first=|date=|website=Youtube|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-11}}</ref><ref name="video" /> Due to the prevalence of marriage in China, these unmarried women are often seen by potential employers as overly particular or otherwise flawed.<ref name="zhangsun"/> The "surplus women" perception promotes gender inequality in the workplace by characterizing unmarried women as inferior.<ref name="zhangsun"/> Older women frequently struggle to find jobs, due to discrimination against their marital status.<ref name="zhangsun"/>
[[File:Chinese matchmaking corner.jpg|thumb|alt=Woman looking at an outdoor display of identical forms|Woman viewing matchmaking ads in China]] In response to the surplus-women issue, many urban parents pursue partners for their older unmarried daughters in matchmaking corners.<ref name="zhangsun"/> These corners are essentially marriage markets; parents place their daughter or son's name and personal information on a card for others to see as they look for a potential match.<ref name="zhangsun"/> Although the success rate for matchmaking corners is low and parents are ashamed of resorting to them, many desperate parents continue to visit the corners on their children's behalf.<ref name="zhangsun"/> A frequent complaint from parents of daughters is a lack of quality men nationwide, despite a surplus of men.<ref name="zhangsun"/> Matchmaking corners illustrate the importance of marriage and the lengths to which parents will go to ensure that their daughters do not become "surplus women".<ref name="zhangsun"/> Due to parental anxiety, women are pressured to marry young (even a flash marriage, at the cost of career and independence) before they see themselves as too old to find a quality husband.<ref name="video" />
[[SK-II]], a Japanese skincare brand, released a video about "leftover women".<ref name="video" /> The video encourages them to live the life they want to live and not let their future be determined by what their parents want or what they have been raised to believe is a good life.<ref name="video" /> Telling the story of several Chinese women over age 27 and their families, it ends with their families' support<ref name="video" /> and calls China's unmarried men "leftover men".<ref name="video" /> The video illustrates the issue's prevalence in China and female resentment of it.<ref name="video">{{cite web|title=Marriage Market Takeover|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=irfd74z52Cw|website=Youtube|accessdate=25 October 2016}}</ref>
=={{anchor|Gendered Social Mobility}}Gendered social mobility== === Hukou system === Originally developed during the Communist era to inhibit mobility between the countryside and the cities (increasing government control), the [[Hukou system]] (household registration system) remains influential.<ref name="Gaetano"/> Under this system, families are registered in a specific region and can only use schools and healthcare in that region.<ref name="Gaetano"/> Since hukou is tied to the maternal line, the system disproportionately affects social mobility for women.<ref name="wu">{{cite journal|last1=Wu|first1=Xiaogang|last2=Treiman|first2=Donald|title=The Household Registration System and Social Stratification in China: 1955–1996|journal=Demography|date=May 2004|volume=41|issue=2|doi=10.1353/dem.2004.0010|pages=363–384}}</ref> Although rural women can travel to cities for work, these migrants have no access to healthcare (due to their rural registration) and limited ability to marry and bear children in the city.<ref name="Gaetano"/> When migrant women have children in the cities, their children have no access to education unless they return home or they pay out of pocket.<ref name="Gaetano"/> Many migrant women are forced to return to the countryside to have children, sacrificing their urban jobs and temporarily separated from their husbands.<ref name="Gaetano"/>
Families with urban registration have significant advantages over those with rural registration.<ref name="wu"/> School-age children from urban families with parental incomes, education, and jobs similar to rural families generally receive two additional years of schooling at higher-accredited and better-funded schools.<ref name="wu"/> Since hukou is passed through the maternal line, the system prevents rural women from giving their children social mobility and perpetuates gender and rural-urban inequality.<ref name="Gaetano"/>
=== {{anchor|Family role & job mobility}}Family role and job mobility === Studies of gender differences in contemporary China have indicated that family concerns affect men's and women's job mobility differently. Women tend to be negatively affected in employment by marriage and family, and a significant job-mobility gender gap exists in urban China. An urban study of job changes found that women tend to experience family-oriented job changes and involuntary terminations, and men tend to experience career-oriented job changes. Women are expected to prioritize family and marriage, and men are expected to prioritize their career. The study noted employer discrimination against, and fewer career opportunities for, married women (who, it is believed, have lower productivity and commitment to work due to family obligations.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cao|first=Yang|last2=Hu|first2=Chiung-Yin|date=2007-06-01|title=Gender and Job Mobility in Postsocialist China: A Longitudinal Study of Job Changes in Six Coastal Cities|url=https://academic.oup.com/sf/article/85/4/1535/2234902|journal=Social Forces|language=en|volume=85|issue=4|pages=1535–1560|doi=10.1353/sof.2007.0065|issn=0037-7732}}</ref> Another study of the urban Chinese labour market demonstrates that the presence of children under age five negatively affects women's employment status and income, but not men's. Women are expected to take care of children and housework, and their roles as wives, mothers and caregivers cause work-family conflicts and constrain job choices. Many women seek a work-family balance by choosing family-friendly jobs ("female-typical" jobs, with lower pay and less opportunity for career advancement) to fulfill their expected responsibilities from work and family.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shu|first=Xiaoling|last2=Zhu|first2=Yifei|last3=Zhang|first3=Zhanxin|date=2007-12-01|title=Global Economy and Gender Inequalities: The Case of the Urban Chinese Labor Market*|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1540-6237.2007.00504.x/abstract|journal=Social Science Quarterly|language=en|volume=88|issue=5|pages=1307–1332|doi=10.1111/j.1540-6237.2007.00504.x|issn=1540-6237}}</ref> A study of unemployment duration among urban Chinese women indicated that married women have a higher layoff rate, longer unemployment periods and less opportunity to be re-employed than married men. In the traditional Chinese view, women are expected to be family caregivers and men are expected to be family breadwinners. Employers (mostly male) tend to protect men's employment and consider it more acceptable to lay off women, who can "take back" their responsibilities in the family after the retreat from employment.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Du|first=Fenglian|last2=Dong|first2=Xiao-yuan|date=2009-03-01|title=Why do women have longer durations of unemployment than men in post-restructuring urban China?|url=https://academic.oup.com/cje/article/33/2/233/1730069|journal=Cambridge Journal of Economics|language=en|volume=33|issue=2|pages=233–252|doi=10.1093/cje/ben034|issn=0309-166X}}</ref>
=== {{anchor|Access to financial resources and other assets}}Access to assets === The traditional Chinese family is patriarchal. This view regulates gender roles and divisions of labor in the family, and affects resource allocation in the family and any family business. Men usually control valuable resources and assets such as land, property, and credit, and can accumulate capital and start a business more easily than women. In a family business, women are usually unpaid labor and entrepreneurial rights and opportunities are reserved for men.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Self-employment in Urban China: The Interplay of Gender, Capitalism and Labor Market|last=Wang|first=Jianying|publisher=|year=2009|isbn=9781109204629|location=|pages=}}</ref>
Women are expected to be family caregivers. In contemporary China, women are also expected to financially contribute to the family (especially in rural China, where economic development is relatively low). In many rural families, men and women will migrate to urban areas to support their rural family. A study of migrant workers in southern China found that women usually spend less and send a larger proportion of their wages back to their rural family than men do.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chow|first=Esther Ngan-Ling|author-link=Esther Ngan-ling Chow|date=2008|title=Paid work, income control, and remittance: Empowering women migrant workers in south China|url=|journal=Paper presented at the Annual Meeting of the American Sociological Association, New York City|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
=== Extracurricular self-development === Institutions and activities for self-improvement have emerged in China, particularly in urban centers. These training activities may foster skills relevant to the job market or focus on self-realization. Many women in China participate such activities, particularly those related to emotional well-being and psychotherapy.<ref>Zhang, Li (2018). [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/01459740.2017.1317769 "Cultivating the therapeutic self in China."] ''Medical Anthropology'' 37 (1): 45-58‏</ref> However, access to these activities is limited by gender. Women often consider their self-improvement as limited to their lives before marriage, since after marriage (unlike men) their main role is caring for children or parents.<ref>Hizi, Gil (2018). [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/14442213.2018.1481881 "Gendered Self-Improvement: Autonomous Personhood and the Marriage Predicament of Young Women in Urban China."] ''The Asia Pacific Journal of Anthropology'': 1-18, DOI: 10.1080/14442213.2018.1481881</ref>
==Media==
=== {{anchor|"Limit of gender"}}Sexuality === Although sexuality was a forbidden topic in Chinese public life, it is prevalent in contemporary China. Sexuality is portrayed as modern, and discussion of the topic is viewed as liberating. Sexual humour and objectification (particularly of young women) pervade mass media to attract audiences, as gender discrimination persists; men and women are still presented in [[stereotypical]] ways. Men are depicted as strong, active, and rational, and women are depicted as the opposite. Sexuality, combined with unacknowledged gender inequality, perpetuates the commodification and marginalization of women in China.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Evans|first=Harrie|date=2008|title=Sexed Bodies, Sexualized Identities, and the Limits of Gender|url=|journal=China Information|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
=== {{anchor|Framing of women issues}}Framing of women's issues === Mainstream media are dominated by marriage and private life as women's issues, rather than gender discrimination and inequality. A study indicated that "delaying marriage and relationship" was the most-frequently-discussed topic by mainstream media. Media focus on women's personal lives, such as marriage and romantic relationships, while gender issues such as "gender discrimination" and "traditional values declined" are ignored.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sun|first=Shengwei|last2=Chen|first2=Feinian|date=2015-10-01|title=Reprivatized Womanhood: Changes in Mainstream Media's Framing of Urban Women's Issues in China, 1995–2012|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jomf.12219/abstract|journal=Journal of Marriage and Family|language=en|volume=77|issue=5|pages=1091–1107|doi=10.1111/jomf.12219|issn=1741-3737}}</ref>
=== {{anchor|''Nüzhubo'' – Female casters on live-streaming sites}}''Nüzhubo'' === ''Nüzhubo'' (female broadcasters) are female performers who [[Live streaming|stream]] themselves performing on live-streaming sites, mostly by singing, dancing, video-game commenting, or eating ([[mukbang]]). "Livestream viewing has become a mainstream pastime with more than 200 active livestreaming platforms and millions of concurrent viewers every day in contemporary China."{{quote without source|date=November 2018}} The live-streaming industry in China is dominated by women, and the growth of the industry is built on the popularity of ''Nüzhubo''. ''Nüzhubo'' earn a living by receiving virtual gifts from followers, and are subject to "constructions of the male gaze" by media and the public.{{quote without source|date=November 2018}} With fierce competition for viewers and followers, most try to attract viewers (especially male viewers) with their appearance. Some are criticized by local and foreign media for their use of sexual content to increase popularity.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zhang|first=Ge|last2=Hjorth|first2=Larissa|title=Live-streaming, games and politics of gender performance: The case of Nüzhubo in China|url=http://journals.sagepub.com.easyaccess1.lib.cuhk.edu.hk/doi/10.1177/1354856517738160|journal=Convergence: the International Journal of Research into New Media Technologies|language=en|doi=10.1177/1354856517738160|year=2017|page=135485651773816}}</ref>

{{Redirect|Working families|the political party|Working Families Party|the advocacy group|Working Families for Wal-Mart}} The phrase "'''hardworking families'''" or "'''working families'''" is an example of a [[glittering generality]] in contemporary [[political discourse]]. It is used in the [[politics of the United Kingdom]] and [[Politics of the United States|of the United States]], and was heavily used by the political parties in the campaign of the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005]] and the [[Australian federal election, 2007]] where the [[Kevin Rudd|Rudd]] Labor Party used the term extensively.
==Origins==
Emerging from some British newspapers around 1995,{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} Gordon Brown expressed gratitude to [[Bob Shrum]] for suggesting the phrase between 1994 and 1997.<ref>Gordon Brown: Prime Minister - ''[[Tom Bower]]'', Harper Perennial (2007)</ref>
== Quotations == Some examples of politicians using (or being reported as using) the phrase: *"She <nowiki>[</nowiki>[[Ann Mallalieu, Baroness Mallalieu|Lady Mallalieu]]<nowiki>]</nowiki> said the protesters wanted to show it was ‘hardworking families’ which would be hit by a hunting ban."<ref>[[BBC News]], 2004-09-28 ([http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3695786.stm "Pro-hunt demo at Labour gathering"])</ref> * "Turning to tax allowances, the married couples' allowance has been abolished, which is a strange move for a government who profess to support the family. They have abolished the [[Mortgage Interest Relief At Source|MIRAS]] tax relief which has hit home-buyers. The change to the allowances for couples with children--the new children's tax credit--which is tapered away for higher rate taxpayers, will affect hardworking families on middle incomes."<ref>[[Lord Northbrook]] recorded in [[Hansard]], 1999-07-23 ([https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld199899/ldhansrd/vo990723/text/90723-01.htm column 1229])</ref> *"Sometimes hard working families need a little help"<ref>the title of [http://www.mpt.org/programsinterests/mpt/hwf/ a monthly half-hour television series] produced by the [[Maryland]] Department of Human Resources and [[Maryland Public Television]]</ref> *"A Conservative government will give hope to hardworking families – decent people who respect others, who take responsibility for their children and who contribute to their local communities."<ref>[[Michael Howard]] speaking in [[Telford]] on 2005-04-10 ([http://www.conservatives.com/tile.do?def=news.story.page&obj_id=121612&speeches=1 "It's time to set an annual limit to immigration"])</ref> * "Then, it was mortgage rates at 15 per cent for a whole year with 1.5 million households suffering [[negative equity]] and over 250,000 families losing their homes—now, hardworking families are enjoying the lowest mortgage rates for 40 years. Then, it was 400,000 more on hospital waiting lists—now, it is almost 300,000 off. Then, it was crime doubled—now, it’s crime down by over a quarter."<ref>[[Alan Milburn]] in ''Agenda: magazine of the Association of Labour Councillors'', winter 2004/5 ([http://www.labour.org.uk/councillors/newsite/agenda/agenda_aut49fw.html "Britain is Working"])</ref> * "WASHINGTON VERSUS HARD-WORKING AMERICAN FAMILIES"<ref>''Frank Luntz Republican Playbook'' at PoliticalStrategy. ORG ([http://www.politicalstrategy.org/archives/001193.php "The Budget: Ending Wasteful Washington Spending"])</ref>
Sometimes the use of the phrase by politicians is echoed in media reports on political events, or indeed the news medium itself employs the phrase as part of its own editorializing, in the expectation that its readers will infer that it is referring to them: * "Meanwhile, the aspirations of ordinary, hardworking families will be the focus of attention for [[Conservative Party (UK)|Tories]] in [[Bournemouth]] this week, their last conference before the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|General Election]]."<ref>''[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]'', 1996-10-07</ref> *"It is equally certain that there will be something for hard-working families after Tony Blair and the Chancellor have made several public announcements about their commitment on this subject."<ref>''[[Daily Telegraph]]'', 2005-03-14 ([https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2005/03/14/nbudg314.xml "At a glance guide to the most likely changes"])</ref> *'Chancellor Gordon Brown says that Tuesday's budget was designed to reward "hardworking families". What a sickening insult to the workers at Longbridge and the dependent factories who face devastation. ... These "hardworking families" now face the dole.'<ref>''[[Socialist Worker]]'', 2000-03-25 ([http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/1689/sw168903.htm "Labour fiddles while Rover burns"])</ref> * In satire: 'I got to do some great Soundbites. My favourites were: "hard working families", "providing opportunity and security", "breaking down barriers" and "on the firm foundations we have laid down since 1997 our programme will embed a new progressive consensus in our country". Who couldn't help but be stirred by the Passion of such sentiments?'<ref>''[[Independent on Sunday]]'', 2005-04-17, ([http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/politics/story.jsp?story=630172 "The Curious Campaign Diary of Tony Blair: Gosh! What a spacematic week"])</ref> * In a letter to the editor: 'Sir: How right Andrew Schofield is (letter, 14 April) about the mantra "hard-working families". Having previously thought my working life fairly productive, I now discover that my single status proves me to have spent 25 years in total indolence. In fact, given that I've always worked in the public service and so can be dispensed with instantly with only benefit to the economy, I must always have been a freeloader of epic proportions. Given this, it would be hardly surprising if I could not be bothered to drag myself from my pit of sybaritic excess to a polling station.'<ref>''[[Independent on Sunday]]'', 2005-04-18, ([http://comment.independent.co.uk/letters/story.jsp?story=630490 letter by J Ambers])</ref>
"Hardworking" is also, by itself, a [[glittering generality]]: * "They hate our people because it is decent, brave, industrious, hardworking and intelligent. They hate our views, our social policies, and our accomplishments. They hate us as a Reich and as a community. They have forced us into a struggle for life and death. We will defend ourselves accordingly. All is clear between us and our enemies." — [[Joseph Goebbels]]' address to [[Germany]], 1939-12-31 <ref>[http://www.calvin.edu/academic/cas/gpa/goeb21.htm "Goebbels New Year Address for 1940"], which in turn cites {{cite book|title=Jahreswechsel 1939/40. Sylvesteransprache an das deutsche Volk|author=Die Zeit ohne Beispiel|location=Munich | publisher=Zentralverlag der NSDAP|year=1941|id=}} pages 229-239.</ref>
==See also == * [[Working Families Party]] * [[Working Families for Wal-Mart]] * Another equivalent in [[Australia]] is the [[Aussie battler]]. * [[Refusal of work]] * [[Working family]], a term used during the lead-up to the Australian federal election, 2007
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://indymedia.org.uk/en/regions/oxford/2005/04/309083.html Hardworking families] — [[indymedia]].org.uk * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/vote_2005/frontpage/4458273.stm Who are 'Britain's hardworking families'? BBC News]
{{Politics of Australia|state=autocollapse}}

In the context of the [[Watergate scandal]], the term '''hatchet man''' was used to refer to a trusted and particularly [[Orthodoxy|orthodox]] subordinate tasked by his employer with destroying a political opponent by any means necessary. [[Charles Colson]] was known as a hatchet man for President [[Richard Nixon]], as was [[H.R. Haldeman]], who proudly described himself as "Richard Nixon's 'son of a bitch'". This use of the term has since become commonplace for anyone who is tasked with conducting distasteful, illegal, or unfair "dirty work" to protect the reputation or power of their employer.<ref name=time>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Humbled Hatchet Man |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,945495,00.html |quote=Of all the men around former President Richard Nixon, probably none was more hated than Chuck Colson, top hatchet man and tireless inventor of dirty tricks. |work=[[Time magazine]] |date=February 2, 1976 |accessdate=2009-02-22 }}</ref>
==Usage== *"Besides being the acting [[United States Secretary of Agriculture|secretary]], [[Chuck Conner|Conner]] was former President [[George W. Bush]]’s hatchet man on payments limits until [[U.S. Congress|Congress]] finally said enough and overrode two vetoes of the farm bill. Chuck Hassebrook has been making those same arguments for 35 years." (2009)<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Not another ‘hatchet man’ at USDA |url=http://deltafarmpress.com/legislative/laws-column-0126/ |quote= |work=Delta Farm Press |year=2009 |accessdate=2009-02-22 }}</ref> *"Of all the men around former President [[Richard Nixon]], probably none was more hated than [[Chuck Colson]], top hatchet man and tireless inventor of dirty tricks." (1976)<ref name=time/> *"In a widely-seen interview in January 2013 on [[CNN]]'s ''[[Piers Morgan Tonight]],'' radio host [[Alex Jones (radio host)|Alex Jones]] called [[Piers Morgan]] a "hatchet man of the [[New World Order (conspiracy theory)|New World Order]]" for his stance in favor of increased [[gun control]] in the United States" <ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/01/07/us/piers-morgan-guns-debate | work=CNN | title=Social media abuzz over Piers Morgan vs. Alex Jones - CNN.com | date=2013-01-09}}</ref>

Vice-President: [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] |era = [[Decolonisation of Asia]] |event_start = |date_start = 2 September |year_start = 1946 |event_end = {{nowrap|[[Indian Independence Act 1947|Indian Independence Act]]}} |date_end = 15 August |year_end = 1947 |event_post = [[Partition of India]] |date_post = 15 August 1947 |stat_year1 = 1947 |stat_area1 = 4226734 |stat_pop1 = |currency = [[History of the rupee|Indian Rupee]] |today = {{unbulleted list |{{flag|Bangladesh}} |{{flag|India}} |{{flag|Pakistan}}| }} |footnote_a = Composed of:
(i) [[Presidencies and provinces of British India|Presidencies and provinces]] directly governed by the [[The Crown|British Crown]] through the [[Governor-General of India]];
(ii) [[Princely state]]s governed by local Indian rulers under the [[suzerainty]] of the British Crown (exercised through the
{{raise|0.3em |Governor-General of India).{{lower|0.4em|Interpretation Act 1889 (52 & 53 Vict. c. 63), s. 18.}} }} |footnote_b = through [[Viceroy's Executive Council|Executive Council]]. |footnote_c = Full title was "Viceroy and Governor-General of India". }} {{Part of History of India}} {{History of Bangladesh}} {{History of Pakistan}} The '''Interim Government of India''', formed on 2 September 1946http://indiatoday.intoday.in/education/story/interim-government/1/463170.html from the newly elected [[Constituent Assembly of India]], had the task of assisting the transition of [[British Raj|British India]] to independence. It remained in place until 15 August 1947, the date of the independence (and partition) of [[Dominion of India|India]], and the creation of [[Dominion of Pakistan|Pakistan]].{{cite book|title=Constitutional history of India, including the nationalist movement|pages=200–10|author=Vidya Dhar Mahajan|publisher=S. Chand|year=1971}}{{cite web|title=Office of the Historian – Countries – India|url=https://history.state.gov/countries/india|publisher=[[U.S. State Department]]|accessdate=2009-08-16}}{{cite book|title=History of Modern India, 1707 A. D. to 2000 A. D.|author=Radhey Shyam Chaurasia|pages=300–400|publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Distributors|year=2002|isbn=978-81-269-0085-5}} ==Formation== After the end of the [[World War II|Second World War]], the British authorities in India released all political prisoners who had participated in the [[Quit India movement]]. The [[Indian National Congress]], the largest Indian political party, which had long fought for national independence, agreed to participate in elections for a [[constituent assembly]], as did the [[All-India Muslim League|Muslim League]]. The newly elected government of [[Clement Attlee]] dispatched the [[1946 Cabinet Mission to India]] to formulate proposals for the formation of a government that would lead to an independent India. The elections for the Constituent Assembly were not direct elections, as the members were elected from each of the provincial legislative assemblies. In the event, the Indian National Congress won a majority of the seats, some 69 per cent, including almost every seat in areas with a majority Hindu electorate. The Congress had clear majorities in eight of the eleven provinces of [[British India]].{{Harv|Judd|2004|p=172}} The Muslim League won the seats allocated to the Muslim electorate. ==Viceroy's Executive Council== The [[Viceroy's Executive Council]] became the executive branch of the interim government. Originally headed by the Viceroy of India, it was transformed into a council of ministers, with the powers of a [[prime minister]] bestowed on the vice-president of the Council, a position held by the Congress leader [[Jawaharlal Nehru]]. After independence all members would be Indians, apart from the Viceroy, in August to become the [[Governor-General of India|Governor-General]], [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma|Lord Mountbatten]], who would hold only a ceremonial position, and the [[Commander-in-Chief, India]], [[Claude Auchinleck|Sir Claude Auchinleck]], replaced after independence by [[Rob Lockhart|General Sir Rob Lockhart]]. The senior Congress leader [[Vallabhbhai Patel]] held the second-most powerful position in the Council, heading the [[Ministry of Home Affairs (India)|Department of Home Affairs]], [[Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (India)|Department of Information and Broadcasting]].{{cite book|title=The History of British India: A Chronology|author=John F. Riddick|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|pages=100–150|year=2006|isbn=978-0-313-32280-8}} The [[Sikh]] leader [[Baldev Singh]] was responsible for the [[Ministry of Defence (India)|Department of Defence]] and [[Chakravarthi Rajagopalachari]] was named to head the [[Ministry of Human Resource Development (India)|Department of Education and arts]]. [[Asaf Ali]], a Muslim Congress leader, headed the [[Ministry of Railways (India)|Department of Railways and Transport]]. [[Scheduled Caste]] leader [[Jagjivan Ram]] headed the [[Ministry of Labour and Employment (India)|Department of Labour]], while [[Rajendra Prasad]] headed the [[Ministry of Agriculture (India)|Department of Food and Agriculture]] and [[John Mathai]] headed the Department of Industries and Supplies. Upon the Muslim League joining the interim government, the second highest-ranking League politician, [[Liaquat Ali Khan]], became the head of the [[Ministry of Finance (India)|Department of Finance]]. [[Abdur Rab Nishtar]] headed the Departments of Posts and Air and [[Ibrahim Ismail Chundrigar]] headed the [[Ministry of Commerce and Industry (India)|Department of Commerce]]. The League nominated a Scheduled Caste Hindu politician, [[Jogendra Nath Mandal]], to lead the [[Ministry of Law and Justice (India)|Department of Law]]. ==Cabinet of the Interim Government of India== {{refimprove|section|date=August 2018}} ===First Interim Cabinet=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Pearson Education India. 2010. pp 28–30. |} ==Activities== Although until August 1947 British India remained under the sovereignty of the [[United Kingdom]], the interim government proceeded to establish diplomatic relations with other countries, including the [[United States]]. Meanwhile, the Constituent Assembly, from which the Interim Government was drawn, struggled with the challenging task of drafting a [[constitution]] for independent India. ==See also== * [[Viceroy's Executive Council]] * [[Council of State (India)]] * [[Imperial Legislative Council]] * [[Central Legislative Assembly]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Indian independence movement}} [[Category:Government of British India]] [[Category:History of the Indian government]] [[Category:Indian independence movement]] [[Category:1940s in India]] [[Category:1946 in India]] [[Category:1947 in India]] [[Category:Constituent Assembly of India]] [[Category:Provisional governments]] [[Category:1946 in British India]] [[Category:1947 in British India]]
