{{based on|''[[WikiLeaks: Inside Julian Assange's War on Secrecy|WikiLeaks]]''|[[David Leigh (journalist)|David Leigh]] and [[Luke Harding]]}} | starring = {{Plain list | *[[Benedict Cumberbatch]] *[[Daniel Brühl]] *[[Anthony Mackie]] *[[David Thewlis]] *[[Alicia Vikander]] *[[Stanley Tucci]] *[[Laura Linney]] }} | music = [[Carter Burwell]] | cinematography = [[Tobias A. Schliessler]] | editing = Virginia Katz | production companies = {{Plain list | *[[DreamWorks|DreamWorks Pictures]] *[[Reliance Entertainment]] *[[Participant Media]] *[[Anonymous Content]] }} | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Walt Disney Studios
Motion Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2013|09|05|[[2013 Toronto International Film Festival|TIFF]]|2013|10|18|United States|2013|10|25|India}} | runtime = 128 minutes{{cite web|title=''THE FIFTH ESTATE'' (15)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/fifth-estate-film|work=[[E1 Films]]|publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=September 26, 2013|accessdate=September 26, 2013}} | country = {{Plain list | *United States{{cite web|title=The Fifth Estate (2013)|url=http://explore.bfi.org.uk/527042cb5b55f|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|accessdate=June 18, 2014}} *India }} | language = English | budget = $28 million{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=fifthestate.htm|title=The Fifth Estate (2013) - Box Office Mojo|publisher=|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} | gross = $8.6 million }} '''''The Fifth Estate''''' is a 2013 [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[thriller film]] directed by [[Bill Condon]], about the [[News leak|news-leaking]] website [[WikiLeaks]]. The film stars [[Benedict Cumberbatch]] as its editor-in-chief and founder [[Julian Assange]], and [[Daniel Brühl]] as its former spokesperson [[Daniel Domscheit-Berg]].{{cite news|title=Benedict Cumberbatch as Julian Assange in the WikiLeaks movie – first picture |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/jan/23/benedict-cumberbatch-julian-assange-first-picture |first=Ben|last=Child|date=January 23, 2013 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=January 23, 2013 |location=London}} [[Anthony Mackie]], [[David Thewlis]], [[Alicia Vikander]], [[Stanley Tucci]], and [[Laura Linney]] are featured in supporting roles.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreamworksstudios.com/films/the-fifth-estate |title=The Fifth Estate |publisher=DreamWorks Studios |date= |accessdate=March 29, 2013}} The film's screenplay was written by [[Josh Singer]] based in-part on Domscheit-Berg's book ''Inside WikiLeaks: My Time with Julian Assange at the World's Most Dangerous Website'' (2011), as well as ''[[WikiLeaks: Inside Julian Assange's War on Secrecy]]'' (2011) by British journalists [[David Leigh (journalist)|David Leigh]] and [[Luke Harding]]. The film's name is a [[Fifth Estate|term used to describe]] the people who operate in the manner of journalists outside the normal constraints imposed on the mainstream media.Dutton, W. H. (2009), "The Fifth Estate Emerging through the Network of Networks", ''Prometheus'', Vol. 27, No. 1, March: pp. 1-15. Co-produced by [[DreamWorks Pictures]] and [[Participant Media]], ''The Fifth Estate'' premiered at the [[2013 Toronto International Film Festival]],{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/jul/23/toronto-film-festival-lineup |title=Toronto film festival 2013: the full line-up |accessdate=July 24, 2013|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=July 23, 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-23419164 |title=Nelson Mandela biopic to have world premiere at Toronto |accessdate=July 24, 2013|work=BBC News|date=July 23, 2013}} and was released in theaters by [[Touchstone Pictures]] in the United States on October 18, 2013,{{cite news|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|title=Pixar's 'The Good Dinosaur' Pushed Back Nearly 18 Months After Losing Director|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/pixars-good-dinosaur-pushed-back-631722|accessdate=September 18, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=September 18, 2013}} with international distribution divided among [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures]], [[Reliance Entertainment]], and independent arrangements by [[Mister Smith Entertainment]].{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/participant-joins-dreamworks-wikileaks-movie-414287 |title=Participant Joins DreamWorks for WikiLeaks Movie 'The Fifth Estate' |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=January 22, 2013 |accessdate=March 29, 2013 |first=Tatiana |last=Siegel}}{{cite web|title=PRODUCTION BEGINS ON DREAMWORKS' WIKILEAKS PROJECT "THE FIFTH ESTATE"|url=http://waltdisneystudios.com/corp/news/1250|work=The Walt Disney Company|publisher=The Walt Disney Studios|accessdate=August 21, 2013|date=August 23, 2013}} The film performed poorly at the box office{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/10392688/Wikileaks-film-The-Fifth-Estate-bombs-at-the-box-office.html|title=Wikileaks film The Fifth Estate bombs at the box office |author=Jon Swaine|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=February 16, 2014|location=London|date=October 20, 2013}} and garnered mixed critical reaction, receiving criticism for its screenplay and direction; the acting was praised, particularly Cumberbatch's performance.{{cite news|last=Lazarus|first=Susanna|title=The Fifth Estate reviews: is this Benedict Cumberbatch's finest performance?|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2013-09-06/the-fifth-estate-reviews-is-this-benedict-cumberbatchs-finest-performance|accessdate=October 14, 2013|newspaper=RadioTimes|date=September 6, 2013}} ==Plot== The story opens in 2010, with the release of the [[Afghan War documents leak|Afghan War Logs]]. It then flashes back to 2007, where journalist [[Daniel Domscheit-Berg]] meets [[Australia]]n computer hacker [[Julian Assange]] for the first time, at the [[Chaos Communication Congress]] in [[Berlin]]. Daniel's interest in online activism has led him to Assange, with whom he has corresponded by email. They begin working together on [[WikiLeaks]], a website devoted to releasing information being withheld from the public while retaining anonymity for its sources. Their first major target is a private Swiss bank, [[Julius Baer]], whose [[Cayman Islands]] branch has been engaged in illegal activities. Despite Baer's [[Bank Julius Baer vs. WikiLeaks|filing of a lawsuit]] and obtaining an injunction, the judge dissolves the injunction, allowing Julian and Daniel to reclaim the domain name. As their confidence increases, the two push forward in publishing information over the next three years, including secrets on [[Scientology]], [[Sarah Palin email hack|revealing Sarah Palin's email account]], and the membership list of the [[British National Party]]. At first Daniel enjoys changing the world, viewing WikiLeaks as a noble enterprise and Assange as a mentor. However, the relationship between the two becomes strained over time. Daniel loses his job and problems arise in his relationship, particularly concerning the BNP membership leak, which also revealed the addresses of the people involved, and caused several to lose their jobs. Assange openly mocks Daniel's concerns about these issues, implying his own life has been more troubling. Assange's abrasive manner and actions, such as abandoning Daniel at his parents' house after having accepted their dinner invitation, only deepen the strain further. Interspersed throughout the film are flashbacks hinting at Assange's troubled childhood and involvement in a suspicious [[cult]], and that Assange's obsession with WikiLeaks has more to do with childhood trauma than wanting to improve the world. Daniel begins to fear that Assange may be closer to a con-man than a mentor. He also notices that Assange constantly gives different stories about why his hair is white. Assange at first tells Daniel that WikiLeaks has hundreds of workers, but Daniel later finds out that Daniel and Assange are the only members. Most importantly to Daniel, Assange frequently claims that protecting sources is the website's number one goal. However, Daniel begins to suspect that Assange only cares about protecting sources so people will come forward and that Assange does not actually care who gets hurt by the website, though Assange claims that the harm the website may cause is outweighed by good the leaks create. Daniel's girlfriend tells him that she believes in his cause, but that it's his job to prevent Assange from going too far. The tensions come to a head when Bradley Manning (later known as [[Chelsea Manning]]) leaks hundreds of thousands of documents to WikiLeaks, including a [[July 12, 2007 Baghdad airstrike|video of an airstrike in Baghdad]], the [[Afghan War documents leak|Afghan]] and [[Iraq War documents leak|Iraq]] War Logs, and 250,000 [[United States diplomatic cables leak|US Diplomatic Cables]]. Assange wants to leak the documents immediately, but Daniel insists that they review the documents first. Later, several major newspapers agree to cooperate with WikiLeaks in releasing the documents while spinning WikiLeaks positively. However, both Daniel and the newspapers require the names in the documents be redacted both to protect sources and to assist in the media spin, to which Assange reluctantly agrees. Daniel realizes that Assange has no intention of following through on this promise and is grooming a right-hand man to replace Daniel. The newspapers release the redacted documents. The resulting media and public uproar forces informants to flee from their countries of residence and many U.S. diplomats to resign. Before Assange can go further, however, Daniel and the other members of the original WikiLeaks team delete the site and block Assange's access to the server. Daniel later talks with a reporter from ''[[The Guardian]]'', and the two fear that giving Assange such a large platform was a mistake. The reporter tells Daniel that while Assange may be untrustworthy, he had done a good thing by uncovering secret dealing in the government and business world and attempting to protect sources. Daniel also reveals the real reason for Assange's hair colour—that it had been a custom of the cult he had been part of in Australia—and reports that he once accidentally discovered Assange dyeing it that colour. As the film ends, it is revealed that WikiLeaks is continuing to leak information (with Assange implied to have either regained the site or rebuilt it), and the Manning documents were released with no redactions. Daniel has written a book on his involvement with the organization on which this film was based, and Assange has threatened to sue in retaliation. Assange is shown to be living in the [[Embassy of Ecuador, London|Ecuadorian embassy]] in [[London]] to avoid arrest on an outstanding warrant for alleged sex crimes. In an interview, he denounces the two upcoming WikiLeaks films, stating that they will be factually inaccurate (having been partly based on Daniel's book). He informs the viewer that individuals are what the government is afraid of and claims that hiring Daniel was the one mistake he made. ==Cast== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | width = | footer = [[Benedict Cumberbatch]] (left) portrayed [[Julian Assange]] (right). | footer_align = center | image1 = Benedict Cumberbatch 2011 (jpg).jpg | width1 = 140 | alt1 = | caption1 = | image2 = Julian Assange cropped (Norway, March 2010).jpg | width2 = 170 | alt2 = | caption2 = }} * [[Benedict Cumberbatch]] as [[Julian Assange]] * [[Daniel Brühl]] as [[Daniel Domscheit-Berg]] * [[Anthony Mackie]] as Sam Coulson * [[David Thewlis]] as [[Nick Davies]] * [[Moritz Bleibtreu]] as Marcus * [[Alicia Vikander]] as Anke Domscheit-Berg * [[Stanley Tucci]] as James Boswell * [[Laura Linney]] as Sarah Shaw * [[Carice van Houten]] as [[Birgitta Jónsdóttir]] * [[Peter Capaldi]] as [[Alan Rusbridger]] * [[Dan Stevens]] as [[Ian Katz]] * [[Alexander Beyer]] as [[Marcel Rosenbach]] * [[Alexander Siddig]] as Dr. Tarek Haliseh * [[Philip Bretherton]] as [[Bill Keller]] * [[Lydia Leonard]] as Alex Lang * [[Hera Hilmar]] as Wikileaks staffer * [[Nigel Whitmey]] as General Thomason ==Production== It was reported in March 2011 that [[Steven Spielberg]]'s [[DreamWorks Studios]] had acquired the rights of Domscheit-Berg's book ''Inside WikiLeaks: My Time with Julian Assange and the World's Most Dangerous Website'', as well as ''WikiLeaks: Inside Julian Assange's War on Secrecy'' by British journalists David Leigh and Luke Harding.{{cite news|author= Brooks, Xan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/mar/02/spielberg-assange-wikileaks-guardian |title=DreamWorks lines up WikiLeaks film based on Guardian book |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=March 2, 2011 |accessdate=March 29, 2013 |location=London}} Spielberg was quick to clarify that he is not involved in any way in the adaptation even though his DreamWorks company would produce the film. In July 2012, reports surfaced that [[Jeremy Renner]] was in talks of playing [[Julian Assange]], and [[Bill Condon]] was in negotiations to direct. It was also announced that [[Josh Singer]] penned the screenplay. Later that year, ''Deadline Hollywood'' broke the news that Renner was out of the running and the studio was seeking [[Benedict Cumberbatch]] instead.{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/07/jeremy-renner-bill-condon-eyeing-wikileaks-film/ |title=Jeremy Renner, Bill Condon Eyeing WikiLeaks Film |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date= |accessdate=March 29, 2013}} [[Joel Kinnaman]] was also attached at some point, but reports were proven to be premature. The confirmation of Cumberbatch as the lead and Condon as the director also brought the news that [[James McAvoy]] was in talks to play [[Daniel Domscheit-Berg]].{{cite web|last=Patten |first=Dominic |url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/11/james-mcavoy-close-to-joining-dreamworks-wikileaks-movie/ |title=James McAvoy "Close" To Joining DreamWorks' WikiLeaks Movie |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date= |accessdate=March 29, 2013}} McAvoy later dropped out because of scheduling conflicts and [[Daniel Brühl]] was eventually cast. In December 2012, the film's title was reported as ''The Man Who Sold the World''{{cite web|author=kauri |url=http://www.onlocationvacations.com/2013/01/06/wikileaks-movie-the-man-who-sold-the-world-headed-to-reykjavik-iceland/ |title=WikiLeaks Movie, 'The Man Who Sold the World', headed to Reykjavík, Iceland |publisher=Onlocationvacations.com |date=January 6, 2013 |accessdate=March 29, 2013}} but with the official press release, it was confirmed that the film's title was actually ''The Fifth Estate''. [[Principal photography]] began on January 23, 2013, with [[Michael Sugar]] and [[Steve Golin]] of [[Anonymous Content]] serving as producers.{{cite news|last=Verrier|first=Richard|title=WikiLeaks movie 'The Fifth Estate' starts production|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jan/23/entertainment/la-et-ct-wikileaks-fifth-estate-dreamworks-20130123|accessdate=October 13, 2013|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=January 23, 2013}} During filming, Cumberbatch had to wear three different wigs, false teeth and blue [[contact lenses]], in order to reflect Julian Assange's physical characteristics.{{cite news|last=Harrison|first=Alexa|title=Benedict Cumberbatch, Stacey Snider Talk Julian Assange at 'Fifth Estate' Screening|url=https://variety.com/2013/scene/news/benedict-cumberbatch-stacey-snider-talk-julian-assange-at-fifth-estate-screening-1200718677/|accessdate=October 14, 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=October 12, 2013}} The film's title sequence, which depicts the history of news communication, took over a year to create.{{cite news|last=Cieply|first=Michael|title=Delivering the News, All of It, in 2 Minutes|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/06/movies/creating-a-prologue-for-fifth-estate.html?_r=1&|accessdate=October 6, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 4, 2013}} The film was partially shot in Belgium, as can be seen in the movie poster, which contains the [[Liège-Guillemins railway station]]. ==Criticism by Assange and Wikileaks== {{quote box|quote=It may be decades before we understand the full impact of WikiLeaks and how it's revolutionized the spread of information. So this film won't claim any long view authority on its subject, or attempt any final judgment. We want to explore the complexities and challenges of transparency in the information age and, we hope, enliven and enrich the conversations WikiLeaks has already provoked. |source=—Director [[Bill Condon]], on the film{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/01/sundance-participant-media-joins-dreamworks-for-wikileaks-movie/ |title=UPDATE: Participant Media Joins DreamWorks For WikiLeaks Movie 'The Fifth Estate' |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date= |accessdate=March 29, 2013}} |width=35%|align=right}} On January 24, 2013, Assange claimed during a presentation of the [[Sam Adams Award]] for Integrity in Intelligence—held at [[Oxford University]]—that he had read the screenplay of the film, describing it as a{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4vQNWYnQjUE#t=699 |title=Julian Assange | Sam Adams Awards | Oxford Union |publisher=YouTube |date=January 25, 2013 |accessdate=March 29, 2013}} "serious propaganda attack on WikiLeaks and the integrity of its staff", as a "lie built upon a lie", and as "fanning the flames for war on Iran".{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.correntewire.com/sunshine_week_transcript_julian_assange_at_sam_adams_awards |title=Sunshine Week transcript! Julian Assange at Sam Adams Awards |publisher=Corrente |date=March 17, 2013 |accessdate=July 17, 2013}} The opening scene was inside a putative military complex in Iran and nuclear symbols could be seen. [[Birgitta Jónsdóttir]] told the WikiLeaks official [[Twitter]] account, "the Iran scene has been written out, plus the name has been changed. Come with constructive ideas how to improve it".{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/birgittaj/status/295109955541942272 |title=Twitter / birgittaj: @wikileaks the Iran scene has |publisher=[[Twitter]] |date= |accessdate=March 29, 2013}} Birgitta also tweeted that Assange does not possess the latest version of the script.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/birgittaj/status/295924900554756096 |title=Twitter / birgittaj: @MeltemArikan not the newest |publisher=[[Twitter]] |date= |accessdate=March 29, 2013}} Although Julian Assange has described the film as a "massive propaganda attack",{{cite news|last=Child|first=Ben|title=WikiLeaks posts The Fifth Estate script and labels film 'irresponsible'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/sep/20/wikileaks-fifth-estate-julian-assange-benedict-cumberbatch|accessdate=October 13, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=September 20, 2013}} he did discuss the film with [[Benedict Cumberbatch]], with Cumberbatch claiming that he's "personally supportive" of the organization.{{cite news|author=Oliver, Sarah |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/event/article-2368613/Julian-Assange-Worst-thing-anyones-said-That-I-mean-cat-turned-psychotic.html?ito=feeds-newsxml |title=Julian Assange: 'Worst thing anyone's said? That I was so mean to their cat it turned psychotic' |publisher=Mail Online |date=July 20, 2013 |accessdate=August 5, 2013 |location=London}} Cumberbatch stated that, "No matter how you cut it, he's done us a massive service, to wake us up to the zombielike way we absorb our news."{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/movies/benedict-cumberbatch-nails-it-as-wikileaks-founder-julian-assange-in-movie/story-e6frfmvr-1226680834359 |title=Benedict Cumberbatch nails it as Wikileaks founder Julian Assange in movie |publisher=new.com.au |date=July 17, 2013 |first=Neala |last=Johnson |accessdate=August 18, 2013}}{{cite news|author=Saunders, Louise |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2366612/The-Fifth-Estate-trailer-Benedict-Cumberbatch-takes-role-WikiLeaks-founder-Julian-Assange.html |title=The Fifth Estate trailer: Benedict Cumberbatch takes on role of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange |publisher=Mail Online |date=July 17, 2013 |accessdate=August 5, 2013 |location=London}} Since Assange has been living inside the [[Embassy of Ecuador, London|Ecuadorian embassy in London]] under [[diplomatic asylum]], he and Cumberbatch reportedly communicated via [[email]] during filming.{{cite news|last=Lewis|first=Hilary|title='Fifth Estate' Screening: Benedict Cumberbatch Talks Challenges of Communicating With Julian Assange|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/fifth-estate-screening-benedict-cumberbatch-648070|accessdate=October 14, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=October 12, 2013}} {{quote box|quote=Our view is that a $US40 million advertising budget promoting WikiLeaks around the world, and actors like Cumberbatch speaking about it, is a good thing for the popularisation of WikiLeaks |source=—[[WikiLeaks]] founder [[Julian Assange]], on the film{{cite web|url=http://www.themercury.com.au/news/breaking-news/wikileaks-thriller-to-open-at-toronto/story-fnj6ehik-1226712808364|title=Acclaim in Toronto for WikiLeaks thriller|publisher=|accessdate=December 11, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://features.rr.com/article/045A75Ben1gvu?q=London|title=Review: Cumberbatch's Assange anchors muddled 'The Fifth Estate'|publisher=|accessdate=December 11, 2016}}[http://localtoday.com.au/index.php?news=102930 Cumberbatch tells secret to Assange accent | Film and TV | Local Today] |width=35%|align=left}} On September 21, 2013, a script, allegedly the film's screenplay, was released by [[WikiLeaks]], along with commentary labeling the film as "fiction masquerading as fact".{{cite news|last=Roxborough|first=Scott|title=WikiLeaks Posts 'Fifth Estate' Script, Calls Assange Film 'Fiction Masquerading as Fact'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/wikileaks-posts-fifth-estate-script-633276|accessdate=October 12, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=September 20, 2013}} Both Assange and WikiLeaks have stated that neither DreamWorks nor Disney approached them for any consultation on the film.{{cite news|last=Labrecque|first=Jeff|title=WikiLeaks leaks 'The Fifth Estate' script, rips 'work of fiction masquerading as fact'|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/09/20/wikileaks-leaks-fifth-estate-script/|accessdate=October 13, 2013|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=September 20, 2013}} Assange elaborated on the matter, "I don't think we are in a situation anymore where an organization like DreamWorks or Disney can succinctly decide that it is going to produce a movie about living people, and living political refugees, and people who are embroiled in a grand jury proceeding in the United States, and just smear, without the cost."{{cite news|last=Pond|first=Steve|title=Assange to Hollywood Foreign Press: 'Fifth Estate' doomed to fail|url=http://www.jamestownsun.com/event/article/id/197267/group/News/|accessdate=October 14, 2013|newspaper=The Jamestown Sun|date=October 13, 2013}} {{quote box|quote= He (Assange) called me one day during the making of the DreamWorks movie, when I was in a supermarket in Camberwell. 'I've got an idea,' he said. 'They'll want you as a consultant on this film. Why don't you say yes to that, and split the fee with me?' 'Because I'm not interested in that,' I said, 'and if you want to oppose the film, why would you also want to make a profit from it?' 'Why not?' he said. |source=—Writer [[Andrew O'Hagan]], recalling Assange's reaction on the film{{cite web|url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v36/n05/andrew-ohagan/ghosting|title=LRB · Andrew O'Hagan · Ghosting: Julian Assange|publisher=|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} |width=35%|align=right}} In October 2013, WikiLeaks published a personal letter that Assange wrote to Cumberbatch in January of that year, in which he commended the actor's talent and good intentions, but requested him to reconsider his involvement with the film, which Assange negatively labeled as "a project that vilifies and marginalises a living political refugee to the benefit of an entrenched, corrupt and dangerous state."{{cite news|last=Hayden|first=Erik|title=WikiLeaks Posts Julian Assange's Disapproving Letter to Benedict Cumberbatch|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/julian-assanges-letter-benedict-cumberbatch-646330|accessdate=October 13, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=October 9, 2013}} WikiLeaks described Cumberbatch's reply to Assange as "courteous and considered". Cumberbatch also admitted his reservations with the early drafts of the film's script, believing that it portrayed Assange as an antagonistic person.{{cite news|last=Aitkenhead|first=Decca|title=The peculiar charm of Benedict Cumberbatch|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/sep/14/benedict-cumberbatch-interview-fifth-estate|accessdate=October 13, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=September 13, 2013|quote=When Cumberbatch first read the script, he worried that it cast Assange as some kind of cartoon baddie. "I think I may get my head bitten off by Disney for saying so, but everyone agreed with that.}} In regard to his continued involvement with the film, Cumberbatch stated "I wanted to create a three dimensional portrait of a man far more maligned in the [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]] press than he is in our film to remind people that he is not just the weird, white haired Australian dude wanted in Sweden, hiding in an embassy behind [[Harrods]]. But a true force to be reckoned with, achieved the realization of the great ideal."{{cite news|last=Hayden|first=Erik|title=Benedict Cumberbatch: Assange's Letter Added 'Real Cause for Concern' About 'Fifth Estate'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/benedict-cumberbatch-assanges-letter-added-647876|accessdate=October 13, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=October 11, 2013}} In an interview with [[George Stephanopoulos]]' show ''[[This Week (ABC TV series)|This Week]]'', Assange stated that "Cumberbatch tried to ameliorate the script but unfortunately with limited success... though I'm pleased he tried."{{cite news| url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2154986,00.html?pcd=pw-edit | work=Time | title=Benedict Cumberbatch Talks Secrets, Leaks, and Sherlock - TIME | date=October 28, 2013}} In February 2014, [[Andrew O'Hagan]], the ghostwriter of Assange's failed autobiography by Canongate, recalled the activist's reaction to the film in a lecture for the London Review of Books. He stated that Assange wanted him to be a consultant of the film and even suggested splitting his fee between the two of them.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/feb/21/julian-assange-ghost-writer-autobiography-wikileaks|title=Julian Assange's ghost writer breaks silence on failed The film opened the [[2013 Toronto International Film Festival|Toronto International Film Festival]] on September 5, 2013.{{cite news|last=Fleming|first=Mike|title=Toronto 2013: Will Deals Take Back Seat As Buyers Focus On Fest Oscar Hopefuls?|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/09/toronto-2013-will-deals-take-back-seat-as-buyers-focus-on-fest-oscar-hopefuls/#more-579958|accessdate=October 14, 2013|newspaper=Deadline Hollywood|date=September 6, 2013}} ===Home media=== [[Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment|Touchstone Home Entertainment]] released the film on [[Blu-ray]] and [[DVD]] on January 28, 2014.{{cite news|last=Truitt|first=Brian|title=The secrets behind a Cumberbatch bunch in 'Fifth Estate'|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2014/01/28/the-fifth-estate-exclusive-clip/4956757/|accessdate=February 4, 2014|newspaper=USA Today|date=January 28, 2014}} ==Reception== ===Box office=== ''The Fifth Estate'' grossed $3.3 million in North America and $5.3 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $8.6 million, against a budget of $28 million. ''The Fifth Estate'' received mixed reviews from film critics, although Cumberbatch's performance as Assange received praise.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1715796/fifth-estate-benedict-cumberbatch-reviews.jhtml|title='The Fifth Estate': What Critics Are Saying About Benedict Cumberbatch |author=Kevin P. Sullivan|publisher=MTV|accessdate=February 16, 2014}} On the review aggregate website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] the film has an approval rating of 37%, based on 170 reviews, with an average rating of 5.4/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "Heavy on detail and melodrama but missing the spark from its remarkable real-life inspiration, ''The Fifth Estate'' mostly serves as a middling showcase for Benedict Cumberbatch's remarkable talent."{{cite web |url= http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_fifth_estate/ |title=The Fifth Estate (2013)|publisher=[[Fandango Media]]|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | accessdate=August 22, 2018}} On [[Metacritic]], which assigns a normalized rating based on reviews, the film has a score of 49 out of 100, based on 42 critics, indicating "mixed to average reviews".{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/the-fifth-estate | title=The Fifth Estate Reviews |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[Metacritic]] | accessdate=October 14, 2013}} It received an average grade of "B" from market-research firm [[CinemaScore]].{{cite web|url=http://cinemascore.com/|title=Cinemascore|publisher=|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' wrote "that it primarily hobbles itself by trying to cram in more context-needy material than any single drama should have to bear."{{cite news|last=Harvey|first=Dennis|title=Toronto Film Review: 'The Fifth Estate'|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/reviews/the-fifth-estate-review-toronto-1200601032/|accessdate=October 14, 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=September 5, 2013}} ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' compared the film unfavorably to ''[[The Social Network]]'', adding that "Though it will attract attention at the box office, it is unlikely to appeal broadly to moviegoers who, one suspects, have never been as worked up about WikiLeaks as journalists and governments are."{{cite news|last=DeFore|first=John|title=The Fifth Estate: Toronto Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/fifth-estate/review/622528|accessdate=October 13, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=September 5, 2013}} Tim Robey of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' reciprocated the comparison, elaborating that, "At times, this debt is so obvious that the movie's style feels second-hand: an overeager, slightly shop-worn bombardment of finger-on-the-pulse pop-out graphics, representing the giddy proliferation of voices in the misinformation age by simply filling the screen with text."{{cite news|last=Robey|first=Tim|title=The Fifth Estate, Toronto Film Festival, review|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/filmreviews/10288755/The-Fifth-Estate-Toronto-Film-Festival-review.html|accessdate=October 14, 2013|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=September 6, 2013|location=London}} Alan Scherstuhl of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' criticized the film for hewing "so closely to [[wikt:template|template]] that it's easy to imagine [[Clippy|that paperclip]] from [[Microsoft Word]] popping up on Condon's desktop one day to say, 'It looks like you're directing a techno-thriller. Would you like help?'"{{cite news|last=Scherstuhl|first=Alan|title=The Fifth Estate Rarely Gives us a Good Look at Julian Assange|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2013-10-16/film/the-fifth-estate/|accessdate=October 17, 2013|newspaper=''[[The Village Voice]]''|date=October 16, 2013}} [[Owen Gleiberman]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' praised the film, describing it as "a vintage journalism thriller, a nihilistic newspaper drama for the dark digital age."{{cite news|last=Gleiberman|first=Owen|title=Toronto 2013: 'The Fifth Estate' is a feverish tale of cyberjournalism|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/09/06/the-fifth-estate-is-a-feverish-tale/|accessdate=October 14, 2013|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=September 6, 2013}} [[Peter Bradshaw]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' gave a positive review, noting that the film "sticks to the ancient movie tradition of depicting journalists as untamed, quasi-bohemian wild men, showing up late, gruff and unshaven in the office."{{cite news|last=Bradshaw|first=Peter|title=The Fifth Estate – review|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/oct/10/the-fifth-estate-review|accessdate=October 14, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=October 10, 2013}} [[Mark Kermode]]'s reaction was mixed, praising the film's cast and cinematography, but disliking the direction, writing that "''The Fifth Estate'' feels strangely unfocused, uncertain of how to deal with its slippery enigma."{{cite news|last=Kermode|first=Mark|title=The Fifth Estate – review|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/oct/13/the-fifth-estate-review|accessdate=October 14, 2013|newspaper=The Observer|date=October 12, 2013}} ''[[Rolling Stone]]'''s [[Peter Travers]] enjoyed the dynamic between Cumberbatch and Brühl, but disliked the focus of the film's subplot.{{cite news|last=Travers|first=Peter|title=The Fifth Estate|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/the-fifth-estate-20131017|accessdate=October 18, 2013|newspaper=Rolling Stone|date=October 17, 2013}} [[Alan Rusbridger]], who worked closely with Assange and is portrayed by [[Peter Capaldi]] in the film, describes Cumberbatch as "stunning as Assange. page.title: United Nations Voluntary Trust Fund for Victims of Trafficking in Persons

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=February 2014}}
On November 4, 2010, U.N. [[Secretary-General]] [[Ban Ki-moon]] launched the '''United Nations Voluntary Trust Fund for Victims of Trafficking in Persons''' to provide [[humanitarian]], legal and financial aid to victims of [[human trafficking]] with the aim of increasing the number of those rescued and supported, and broadening the extent of assistance they receive.
The Fund was established in accordance with resolution A/RES/64/293 Article 38 of the [[United Nations General Assembly|General Assembly]] on 12 August 2010 - United Nations [[Global Plan of Action to Combat Trafficking in Persons]].
To ensure efficient, transparent, and accountable Fund administration and to support uniform and consolidated reporting, the [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime]] (UNODC) is designated as the Fund Manager for the Fund.
==External links== {{Commons category|Human trafficking}} * [http://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/human-trafficking-fund.html UN Voluntary Trust Fund for Victims of Human Trafficking] * [http://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/human-trafficking/index.html UNODC Trafficking in Persons]
==See also== * [[Human Trafficking]] * [[Global Plan of Action to Combat Trafficking in Persons]] * [[Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, especially Women and Children]]

'''Voluntary Emission Reductions''' or '''Verified Emission Reductions''' (VERs) are a type of [[carbon offset]] exchanged in the voluntary or over-the-counter market for [[carbon credits]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Building Bridges: State of the Voluntary Carbon Markets 2010 |url= http://moderncms.ecosystemmarketplace.com/repository/moderncms_documents/vcarbon_2010.2.pdf |publisher=Ecosystem Marketplace & Bloomberg New Energy Finance |accessdate=2010-10-18 |date=2010-06-14 |first=Katherine |last=Hamilton, |first2=Milo |last2=Sjardin, |first3=Molly |last3=Peters-Stanley and |first4=Thomas |last4=Marcello |quote= Credits sourced specifically for the OTC market are often generically referred to as Verified (or Voluntary) Emission Reductions (VERs) (p 9) }}</ref> Verified Emission Reductions are usually certified through a voluntary certification process.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.firstclimate.com/popup/verified-emission-reductions.html |title= Verified Emission Reductions |publisher=First Climate |year=2010 |accessdate=2010-10-18 |quote=A VER project has its GHG emission reductions certified under a voluntary certification process. VERs (Verified Emission Reductions) can be traded on the so-called voluntary carbon market }}</ref>
Verified Emission Reductions are usually created by projects which have been verified outside of the [[Kyoto Protocol]]. One VER is equivalent to 1 tonne of CO2e emissions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ecosecurities.com/Footers/Glossary/default.aspx |title=VER - Verified Emission Reduction |work= Glossary |publisher=EcoSecurities Group plc |location=Ireland |accessdate=2010-10-19 }}</ref> Through these schemes, industries and individuals voluntarily compensate for their emissions or provide an additional contribution to mitigating climate change.
VERs may be developed and calculated in compliance with one of several VER standards. These set out rules defining how emission reductions are measured. Standards provide assurance for buyers of VERs.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ecosecurities.com/Home/Creating_emission_reductions/VER_Projects/default.aspx |title=Developing voluntary market projects to produce Verified Emission Reductions (VERs) - VER Projects |publisher=EcoSecurities Group plc |accessdate=2010-10-19 }}</ref> At a minimum, all VERs should be verified by an independent third party.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cdmupdate.com/saqver.asp#qtver |title=Sources of VERs, Types of VER, Land use change, Carbon Capture storage, biofuels, Forestry, Afforestation |publisher=CDM Update |accessdate=2010-10-19 }}</ref>
== See also == *[[CEB VER]] *[[Voluntary Carbon Standard]] *[[CDM Gold Standard]] *[[Certified Emission Reduction]]

'''War pensions''' are almost certainly the most ancient type of [[social security]]. Plutarch's Life of [[Solon]] mentions a law which provides that those who are maimed in war shall be maintained at the public charge. [[Halsbury's Laws of England]] traced their history back to the days of King Alfred. Until 1978 the British War Pension scheme was run entirely under the [[Royal Prerogative]] and completely without legislation.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ogus|first1=A I|last2=Barendt|first2=EM|last3=Buck|first3=TG|last4=Lynes|first4=T|title=The Law of Social Security|date=1988|publisher=Butterworths|location=London|isbn=978-0406633705|page=313|edition=3rd}}</ref> [[File:Penzance War Pension Committee.jpg|thumb|Penzance War Pension Committee in the Scilly Isles museum]]

'''Water grabbing''' involves the distribution of [[water resources]] in a way that leaves one or more parties feeling the distribution is less equitable.
It also can have [[Environmental degradation|damaging environmental effects]] as watersheds are made unsustainable by [[overexploitation|overuse]] of limited water.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Franco|first=Jennifer|title=Water Grabbing? Focus on the (Re)appropriation of Finite Water Resources, Water Alternatives Journal |journal=Water Alternatives Journal|url=http://www.water-alternatives.org/index.php/volume5/v5issue2/165-a5-2-1 |date=March 2012<!--|date=June 2012-->|author2=Lyla Mehta|author3=Gert Jan Veldwisch}}</ref>
